Introduction: Japheth, Noah's eldest son, is a character in the Bible, Book of Genesis. His name derives from a Hebrew root meaning “to enlarge” or “expand,”<sup>1</sup> , a meaning that resonates with Noah’s blessing: “May God enlarge Japheth.”<sup>2</sup>

Genesis 10:2-5 lists Japheth’s descendants as Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras. Over the ages some have tried to link Gomer to different ethnic groups, from the Cimmerians of Anatolia to the Cimbri of what is now Denmark, to the Welsh, based on speculation and the sounds of names.<sup>3</sup> Javan was associated with Greeks<sup>4</sup>; Madai with Medes, Kurds, and Azeris;<sup>5</sup> Tubal with Georgians, although some Christian scholars in 300-700 CE began a tradition of associating him with people from the Iberian Peninsula (now Portugal and Spain) and other places;<sup>6</sup> we will not be exhaustive.
Through these legendary genealogical connections, Japheth came to be regarded by some as the forefather of many Indo-European and Eurasian peoples.

簡介: 雅弗（Japeth）是挪亞（Noah）的長子，聖經《創世記》中的人物。他的名字源自希伯來語詞根，意為「擴大」或「擴展」<sup>1</sup>，這與挪亞的祝福相呼應：「願神使雅弗得以擴張」。<sup>2</sup>

《創世記》10章2至5節列出雅弗的後裔，包括歌篾（Gomer）、瑪各（Magog）、瑪代（Madai）、雅完（Javan）、土巴（Tubal）、米設（Mesheeh）和提拉斯（Tiras）<sup>3</sup>。歷史上有人試圖將歌篾與不同民族聯繫起來，從安納托利亞（Anatolia）的西米爾人（Cimmerians）到今丹麥的辛布里人 (Cimbri），再到威爾士人，這些聯繫多基於推測和名字的音近。雅完被認為與希臘人有關<sup>4</sup>；瑪代與米底人（Medes）、庫爾德人（Kurds）和亞塞拜然人（Azeris）<sup>5</sup>相關 ；土巴則與喬治亞人相關，儘管部分基督教學者在公元300至700年間開始將他與伊比利亞半島（今葡萄牙和西班牙）及其他地區的人聯繫起來<sup>6</sup>，我們此處不再詳盡列舉。
透過這些傳說中的族譜連結，雅弗被部分人視為許多印歐語系和歐亞大陸民族的祖先。

補充説明.安納托利亞: 安納托利亞（Anatolia），或稱小亞細亞（Asia Minor），是位於西亞的一個半島，構成土耳其大部分的陸地面積。
補充説明.米底人: 梅德人（Medes）是公元前第一千紀左右居住在伊朗西北部的古代伊朗民族。
補充説明.庫爾德人: 庫爾德人（Kurds）是古老的印歐民族，原居於被稱為庫爾德斯坦（Kurdistan）的山區地帶，該地區涵蓋現今土耳其、伊朗、伊拉克和敘利亞的部分地區。
補充説明.亞塞拜然人: 亞塞拜然人（Azeris）是主要分布在亞塞拜然和伊朗西北部的突厥語民族。

Introduction: Ham, the third son of Noah, in the Bible, Book of Genesis. Following the flood, the Book of Genesis (English Standard Version, 2001) recounts that Noah planted a vineyard, drank wine, and became intoxicated. While Noah lay naked inside his tent, his youngest son Ham saw his father’s nakedness and informed his brothers Japheth and Shem. In contrast, Japheth and Shem respectfully covered their father with a cloak without looking at him. When Noah awoke and learned of Ham’s actions, he blessed Japheth and Shem but cursed Ham’s son, Canaan:
“Blessed be the Lord God of Shem and may Cannan be his slave, and may God enlarge Japeth, and may he dwell in the tents of Shem, and may Canaan be his slave!”1

Stirling, in his review of David M. Goldberg’s book, The Curse of Ham: Race and Slavery in Early Judaism, Christianity, and Islam reports that Goldberg says that the ideas of “Ham’s curse” and the association of Ham with black Africans arose around 800 CE in Arabia and then was taken up “the Christian west” in the fifteenth century in Europe and the Americas as a justification for slavery., and grew more common2. Another scholar, Braude, states, “It was not until the eighteenth century, the height of the [transatlantic] slave trade, that the curse of Ham came to gain broad acceptance.”3

Genesis 10:6-14 lists Ham’s descendants: his sons, Cush, Egypt, Put, and Canaan. This led to a long tradition of considering  Ham the ancestor of several ancient peoples, including  people from  “Cush”<sup>4</sup>, which likely related to the area of the Kingdom of Kush  (present day Egypt and Sudan)<sup>5</sup> and Canaan (a vague and wide area corresponding much of the eastern Mediterranea including  modern-day Israel, Palestine, Lebanon, and parts of Syria and Jordan ).<sup>6</sup>

簡介: 含（Cam）是挪亞（Noah）的第三個兒子，出自聖經《創世記》。洪水過後，《創世記》（英文標準版，2001年）記載挪亞種植葡萄園，飲酒後醉倒，赤身躺在帳篷內。含看到父親的裸身，告訴了他的兩個兄弟雅弗（Japheth）和閃（Shem）。相反地，雅弗和閃則尊敬地用衣服遮蓋父親，且沒有看他的身體。當挪亞醒來得知含的行為後，祝福了雅弗和閃，卻詛咒含的兒子迦南（Canaan）：
「願閃的神─耶和華受祝福，願迦南作他的僕人；願神使雅弗擴張，使他居住在閃的帳棚裡，願迦南作他的僕人！」1

根據Stirling對David M. Goldberg《含的詛咒：早期猶太教、基督教與伊斯蘭教中的種族與奴隸制》 （The Curse of Ham: Race and Slavery in Early Judaism, Christianity, and Islam） 一書的評論，Goldberg指出「含的詛咒」以及將含與非洲黑人聯繫的觀念約於公元800年在阿拉伯興起，十五世紀時被歐洲及美洲的基督教西方用作奴隸制的正當化，且此觀念逐漸普及<sup>2</sup> 。另一學者Braude表示，「直到十八世紀跨大西洋奴隸貿易高峰期，含的詛咒才被廣泛接受」。<sup>3</sup>
《創世記》10章6至14節列出含的後裔：其子為古實（Cush）、埃及、弗（Put）、迦南。這導致長期以來將含視為多個古代民族的祖先，包括「古實」<sup>4</sup>，可能指古實王國（現今埃及與蘇丹地區）<sup>5</sup>，以及迦南（涵蓋東地中海廣泛地區，包括現今以色列、巴勒斯坦、黎巴嫩及敘利亞和約旦部分地區）。

Introduction: In the Bible, Genesis, chapter 6, the sons of Noah are listed as Shem, Ham, and Japheth.<sup>1</sup> Then, in chapter 10, it lists the son of Shem: Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad (or Arphaxad), Lud, and Aram.<sup>2</sup>
Through his son Arpachshad, Shem was ancestor of Abram (later Abraham)<sup>3</sup>, the patriarch revered by Jews, Christians, and Muslims.
However, as the scholar Braude points out, the genealogies in the Bible and then the “associated” peoples to a certain continent are a mix of myth, conjecture, and pseudo-science:

“The genealogical listing of chapter 10 is repetitive, contradictory, and manifestly incomplete: it lists sons without daughters; not surprisingly, it is accompanied by no map; most of the names are unidentifiable, and, to the questionable extent that they have been identified, they do not fit modern geographical, ethnic, or linguistic principles of organization. Although this list is the source of the modern linguistic term, "Semitic languages," and the pseudoanthropological racial term, "Semite," the two groupings do not correspond. Thus Cush, the son of Ham, whom most, but by no means all, commentary has identified with Ethiopia, fathered a people who speak Semitic languages. Furthermore, Cush's son Nimrod, who provoked more pages of exegesis than any other figure in this genealogy, is located by almost all in the Asiatic and presumably Semitic stronghold of Mesopotamia . Many of the sons of Japhet, the so-called European, can be linked to Asia Minor and Central Asia”.4

Braude argues that it was not until after the publication of the Nuremberg Chronicle (where the sons appear as medium-brown Mediterranean types)5 that the association of the sons of Noah with different continents became part of the popular imagination in Europe with the publication of John Mandeville’s Travels in the 14th century CE.6

hoverText.Mesopotamia: Mesopotamia is an ancient region located between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. It is the birthplace of some of the world’s earliest civilizations, including Sumer, Assyria, and Babylon.
hoverText.Asia Minor: Asia Minor, also called Anatolia, is a peninsula in western Asia, mostly in modern-day Turkey. It lies between the Black Sea, the Mediterranean Sea, and the Aegean Sea, and connects to Europe near Istanbul. It has been a historic crossroads of civilizations.

簡介: 根據聖經《創世記》第6章，挪亞的兒子列為閃 (Shem)、含(Ham)、雅弗(Japheth)<sup>1</sup>。第10章則列出閃的子孫：以攔 (Elam)、亞述(Asshur)、亞法薛(Arpachshad，或稱Arphaxad)、路德(Lud)和亞蘭(Aram)<sup>2</sup>。藉由他的兒子亞法薛，閃成為亞伯蘭(Abram)（後稱亞伯拉罕[Abraham]）的祖先<sup>3</sup>，亞伯拉罕是猶太教、基督教和伊斯蘭教共同尊崇的族長。
然而，學者Braude指出，聖經中的族譜及將其「關聯」於特定大陸的說法，混合了神話、推測與偽科學：

「第10章的族譜重複、矛盾且明顯不完整：只列出兒子不提女兒；也沒有附地圖；大多數名字無法辨認，且即使被辨認，也不符合現代地理、族群或語言的組織原則。雖然這份名單是現代語言學上‘閃米特語言’(Semitic languages)一詞及偽人類學種族詞‘閃米特人’(Semite)的來源，但兩者並不相符。例如，含的兒子古實(Cush)，多數（但非全部）註釋認為是埃塞俄比亞，卻生出講閃米特語的民族。此外，古實的兒子尼姆羅德(Nimrod)，在這族譜中引發最多詮釋，幾乎所有人都將他定位於亞洲且推測為閃米特人據點的美索不達米亞 (Mesopotamia)。雅弗的許多兒子，所謂的歐洲人，可以連結到小亞細亞 (Asia Minor)和中亞。」4
Braude主張，直到《紐倫堡編年史》(Nuremberg Chronicle)出版後（書中將挪亞三子描繪為中棕色地中海人種）<sup>5</sup>，以及14世紀約翰·曼德維爾(John Mandeville)的《遊記》(Travels)發表，挪亞三子與不同大陸的聯想才成為歐洲普遍的想像<sup>6</sup>。

補充説明.美索不達米亞: 美索不達米亞(Mesopotamia)是位於底格里斯河(Tigris)與幼發拉底河(Euphrates)之間的古代地區，是世界最早文明的發源地，孕育了蘇美爾(Sumer)、亞述(Assyria)和巴比倫(Babylon)等古國。
補充説明.小亞細亞: 亞洲小亞細亞(Asia Minor)，又稱安納托利亞(Anatolia)，是位於西亞的半島，主要位於現今土耳其境內。它介於黑海(Black Sea)、地中海(Mediterranean Sea)和愛琴海(Aegean Sea)之間，並在伊斯坦布爾(Istanbul)附近與歐洲相連。此地區歷史悠久，是多個文明的交匯點。

Introduction: In Roman mythology, the name Septentrio derives from septem triones (“seven oxen”), a poetic reference to the seven prominent stars of the northern constellation Ursa Major. This celestial connection underscores Septentrio’s role not only as a wind but as a symbol of the northern direction itself.<sup>1</sup>

And in Greek mythology, Septentrio, also known as Boreas, dwelled in Thrace, north of Greece, where his fierce breath whipped the open sea into a frenzy and made the earth and forests howl in the wind. His power was such that he uprooted mighty oaks and thick-branched pines, and even animals, despite their thick fur, shivered in fear and cold before his relentless chill.<sup>2</sup>

Eidinow described how the north wind had a “widespread reputation for violence” that fuelled its mythic prominence. Among the tempestuous quartet of wind siblings—Subsolanus (East), Auster (South), and Favonius (West)—Septentrio stands out, attracting the most elaborate and vivid mythic narratives<sup>3</sup>.

In Greek mythology, Septentrio is known as Boreas, son of the Titan Astraeus and the goddess of Dawn, Eos. He is brother to Notus (South wind) and Zephyrus (West wind), together forming the legendary Anemoi, the personifications of the cardinal winds.<sup>4</sup>

Eidinow vividly portrays Septentrio as a harbinger of wintry chaos, often stirring treacherous storms at sea. Drawing on Herodotus’s Histories, she recounts the north wind’s destructive role in the shipwreck of the Persian fleet sent to attack the Greeks near Mount Athos in 492 BCE. This disaster is echoed in the poignant lament she found from a different source, of a sailor lost near the Mykale promontory close to Samos:

“This is not the tomb of poor Satyros; Satyros sleeps not, as they tell, under the ashes of this pyre. But perchance you have heard of a sea somewhere, the bitter sea that beats on the shore near Mykale where the wild-goats feed, and in that eddying and desert water yet I lie, reproaching furious Boreas.”

Septentrio’s volatile nature extends beyond storms and tempests. According to Ancient History and Latin expert Gill,, Boreas carries a darker legacy as the abductor and rapist of the Athenian princess Orithyia, daughter of King Erechtheus and Praxithea. Spurned in his courtship, Boreas seized Orithyia as she played by the Ilissos River, whisking her away to Thracian Cicones, enveloping her in a storm cloud, and violating her<sup>5</sup>. From this brutal union were born two daughters, Cleopatra and Chione, and the winged sons Zetes and Calais.

簡介: 在羅馬神話中，Septentrio一名源自septem triones（「七頭牛」），詩意地指北方大熊座的七顆顯著星星。這一天體聯繫強調了Septentrio不僅是風的象徵，更是北方方向的象徵。<sup>1</sup>
在希臘神話中，Septentrio也被稱為波瑞阿斯（Boreas），居住在希臘北方的色雷斯（Thrace）。他那猛烈的氣息將開闊的海面攪動成狂暴，使大地和森林在風中呼嘯。他的力量強大，能連根拔起巨大的橡樹和枝葉茂密的松樹，即使是厚毛的動物也在他無情的寒風前顫抖，既害怕又感到寒冷。<sup>2</sup>
Eidinow述北風因其「廣為人知的暴力」而在神話中占有重要地位。在風神四兄弟中——東風（Subsolanus）、南風（Auster）和西風（Favonius）——Septentrio 最為突出，擁有最豐富生動的神話故事。<sup>3</sup>
在希臘神話中，Septentrio即Boreas，是泰坦Astraeus與黎明女神Eos之子，Notus（南風）和Zephyrus（西風）的兄弟，合稱四方風神Anemoi。<sup>4</sup>
Eidinow生動描繪Septentrio為冬季混亂的先兆，常在海上掀起危險風暴。她援引希羅多德（Herodotus）的《歷史》(Histories)記載，北風在公元前492年波斯艦隊在阿索斯山(Mount Athos)附近遭遇船難的毀滅性角色。她還引述一位在薩摩(Samos)附近米卡勒岬(Mykale)失蹤水手的哀歌：
「這不是可憐的薩提羅斯(Satyros)的墳墓；薩提羅斯並未如人所說，安眠於此焚燒的灰燼下。但或許你聽說過某處海洋，那苦澀的海浪拍打著米卡勒附近野山羊覓食的岸邊，而我仍在那漩渦與荒涼的水域中，責備狂暴的Boreas。」
Septentrio的多變性不止於風暴。古史與拉丁專家Gill指出，Boreas還有黑暗的傳說，為雅典公主Orithyia的綁架者與強暴者。被拒絕追求後，Boreas在Ilissos河邊抓走Orithyia，帶她至色雷斯Cicones地區，籠罩在風暴雲中，對她施暴<sup>5</sup>。這段殘酷聯姻誕生了兩女Cleopatra和Chione，以及有翼的兒子Zetes和Calais。
這強烈的意象在1590年荷蘭版畫家Crispijn de Passe the Elder的版畫中得以視覺呈現，Septentrio以赤裸、長鬍鬚、長翅膀的形象出現，從手中撒下冰雪，覆蓋荒涼寒冬的世界。

Introduction: Aquilo, the Roman counterpart of the Greek god Boreas—who is sometimes also called Septentrio in Roman myth—is renowned for his violent and tempestuous nature. Born to the dawn goddess Eos and the starry titan Astraeus, Aquilo stands apart from his siblings: Subsolanus (the East wind, or Eurus in Greek mythology), Auster (the South wind, or Notus), and Favonius (the West wind, or Zephyrus), as noted by Eidinow<sup>1</sup>. This divine lineage underscores Aquilo’s role as a formidable force of nature, embodying the harshness of winter’s chill.

One of the most evocative moments featuring Boreas appears in Homer’s Iliad, where he and his brother Zephyrus assist in fanning the funeral pyre of Patroclus, which stubbornly refuses to ignite. Achilles, desperate to honor his fallen friend, prays fervently:

“But the pyre of dead Patroclus was not burning – and the swift runner Achilles thought of what to do. Stepping back from the pyre he prayed to the two winds – Zephyr and Boreas, West and North – promised splendid victims and pouring generous, brimming cups from a golden goblet, begged them to come, so the wood might burst in flame and the dead burn down to ash with all good speed.”2
This mythic scene vividly illustrates the winds’ divine agency, summoned by human devotion and divine will alike.

Though Aquilo is often broadly identified as the north wind god, classical sources specify his wind direction more precisely. Pliny the Elder, in his Natural History, clarifies this distinction:, stating “Septentrio from the North and Aquilo between him and sunrise at the solstice (N.E.)—called in Greek Aparctias and Boreas.”3
Here, Pliny distinguishes Septentrio as the true north wind, while Aquilo occupies the north-northeast position, a nuance that reflects the sophistication of Roman meteorological knowledge.

This distinction is crucial. While both Aquilo and Septentrio are associated with the north or northeast winds in Roman tradition, Septentrio carries a more symbolic and astronomical significance, deriving its name from the seven stars (septem triones) of the Big Dipper constellation, a celestial marker of the northern direction. Aquilo, by contrast, is the personified god of the cold north-northeast wind, a fierce and tempestuous force bringing winter storms and chill.<sup>4</sup>

Artistically, Aquilo was frequently depicted as a winged old man, his shaggy hair and beard whipped by the wind, draped in a billowing cloak. Often, he holds a conch shell, symbolizing his command over the air and storms. This imagery captures both his power and his elemental connection to the cold northern winds.<sup>5</sup>

簡介: 阿奎羅（Aquilo），是羅馬神話中對應希臘北風之神玻瑞阿斯（Boreas）的神祇，有時在羅馬神話中亦被稱為塞普滕特里奧（Septentrio），以其猛烈與暴躁的本性聞名。他是黎明女神厄俄斯（Eos）與繁星泰坦阿斯特瑞烏斯（Astraeus）之子，與兄弟們截然不同：東風之神蘇布索拉努斯（Subsolanus，希臘神話中的歐羅斯Eurus）、南風之神奧斯特（Auster，希臘神話中的諾圖斯Notus）、以及西風之神法沃尼烏斯（Favonius，希臘神話中的澤費洛斯Zephyrus）<sup>1</sup>。這一神聖血脈突顯了阿奎羅作為自然強大力量的角色，體現了冬季嚴寒的殘酷。
在荷馬史詩《伊利亞德》（Iliad）中，玻瑞阿斯的經典場景之一，是他與兄弟澤費洛斯（Zephyrus）協助點燃帕特羅克洛斯（Patroclus）的葬火堆。當火堆遲遲不燃，阿基里斯（Achilles）焦急地祈禱：
「但帕特羅克洛斯的葬火並未燃燒——迅捷的阿基里斯思索著對策。他退後離開火堆，向兩位風神祈禱——澤費洛斯與玻瑞阿斯，西風與北風——許下豐盛的祭品，並用金杯盛滿美酒，懇求他們前來，使柴木熊熊燃燒，讓亡者儘速化為灰燼。」2
這一神話場景生動展現了風神的神力，既可被人類虔誠所召喚，也受神意驅使。
雖然阿奎羅常被廣泛認為是北風之神，但古典文獻對其風向有更精確的定義。老普林尼（Pliny the Elder）在其《自然史》（Natural History）中明確指出：「塞普滕特里奧自正北吹來，阿奎羅則位於其與夏至日出之間（即北北東），希臘人稱之為阿帕克提亞斯（Aparctias）與玻瑞阿斯」。<sup>3</sup>
在此，普林尼區分了塞普滕特里奧為真正的北風，而阿奎羅則位於北北東，這一細微差異反映出羅馬氣象知識的精細。
這一區分極為關鍵。雖然阿奎羅與塞普滕特里奧在羅馬傳統中都與北或東北風相關，塞普滕特里奧更具象徵與天文意義，其名稱來自大熊座七星（septem triones），作為北方的天體標誌。相比之下，阿奎羅則是北北東寒風的擬人化神祇，是帶來冬季風暴與嚴寒的兇猛力量。<sup>4</sup>
在藝術表現中，阿奎羅常被描繪為一位長有翅膀的老者，蓬亂的頭髮與鬍鬚被風揚起，身披飄動的斗篷，手持海螺，象徵他對空氣與風暴的掌控。這一形象既展現了他的力量，也表現出他與寒冷北風的本質聯繫。<sup>5</sup>

Introduction: In Greek and Roman mythology, Circus—also known as Thrascias or Thracius—is the fierce north-northwest wind, renowned for its swirling, dizzying motion. This characteristic circular movement is famously noted by the Hispano-Roman scholar Isidore of Seville (c. 560 636 CE)
“Circius is named because it is next to Corus. The Spanish call it Gallicus, because it blows on them from the direction “of Galicia.”1;

500 years earlier, the  Roman author Aulus Gellius (c. 125- 180 CE), “Thus our Gauls  call the wind which blows from their land, the most violent wind to which they are exposed, circius, doubtless from its whirling and stormy character.”<sup>2</sup>
Havadas in the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle notes:

“Circius (Cercius) vel Tracias (Thracias): Circius has been defined as a violent wind blowing in Gallia Narbonensis; perhaps from circus, on account of its circular motion. To the Romans it meant a west-northwest wind. Thrascias (Thracias, or Tracias, as it is spelled in the Chronicle), is the north-northwest wind, and is therefore not exactly synonymous with Circius, a west-northwest wind. The name Thrascias probably had its origin in the fact that Boreas and his satellites had their home in Thrace, from whence they blew for better or for worse”3

hoverText.Gallia Narbonensis: Gallia Narbonensis was a Roman province in what is now southern France, covering parts of Occitania and Provence, bordered by the Pyrenees, Cévennes, Alps, and the Mediterranean Sea.

簡介: 在希臘與羅馬神話中，Circius亦稱為Thrascias或Thracius，是猛烈的北北西風，以其旋轉且令人眩暈的運動聞名。這種特有的環繞旋轉運動由西班牙羅馬學者塞維利亞的伊西多爾（Isidore of Seville，約公元560–636年）著名地記載：
「Circius之名來自於它緊鄰Corus（西風）。西班牙人稱之為Gallicus，因為它從『加利西亞』(Galicia)方向吹來。」1
約五百年前，羅馬作家奧勒斯·蓋留斯（Aulus Gellius，約公元125–180年）記載：
「我們的高盧人稱從他們土地吹來的風為Circius，這是他們所遭遇的最猛烈的風，無疑是因為它旋轉且暴風驟雨的特性。」2
在《紐倫堡編年史》(Nuremberg Chronicle)的英文譯本中，Havadas指出：

「Circius（Cercius）或稱Tracias（Thracias）：Circius被定義為吹拂加利亞納爾波寧西斯（Gallia Narbonensis）地區的猛烈風；或許因其環繞旋轉的運動而得名Circus。對羅馬人而言，它是西北偏西風。Thrascias（Thracias，或編年史中拼為Tracias）是北北西風，因此並不完全等同於Circius（西北偏西風）。Thrascias這名稱可能源自Boreas（北風神）及其隨從居住於色雷斯（Thrace），他們從那裡吹來，無論好壞。」3

Introduction: Subsolanus, known as Apeliotes in Greek mythology, is the god of the pure east wind in Roman tradition. Roman sailors called it “the wind that comes from the rising sun,” hence its name meaning “lying beneath the sun.”<sup>1</sup>

This wind was considered wet, bringing light showers, and “On the Tower of the Winds at Athens, it is represented as the bringer of blessings; its lap is filled with honeycomb, grain and fruits.”<sup>2</sup>
Subsolanus’s nature made it a favorable force in agricultural contexts. Villas and vineyards in healthful regions were advised to face Subsolanus.<sup>3</sup>
Pliny the Elder, in his Natural History, records similar advice for villas in temperate regions but notes that in hot places, they should face north, and in cold places, south:

“..from this quarter the wind Subsolanus blows, by the Greeks called Apeliotes. It is to this point that, in healthy localities, farm-houses and vineyards are made to look. This wind is accompanied with soft, gentle showers;.”4

簡介: Subsolanus，在希臘神話中稱為Apeliotes，是羅馬傳統中純淨東風之神。羅馬水手稱這風為「來自旭日的風」，因此其名稱意指「位於太陽之下」。<sup>1</sup>
這股風被認為是濕潤的，帶來細雨輕霧，並且「在雅典的風之塔(Tower of the Winds)上，它被描繪為帶來祝福的使者；其懷中裝滿蜂巢、穀物和水果。」<sup>2</sup>
Subsolanus的特性使其在農業環境中被視為有利的力量。建議健康地區的莊園和葡萄園面向Subsolanus。<sup>3</sup>
老普林尼（Pliny the Elder）在其《博物志》（Natural History）中也記錄了類似的建議，針對溫帶地區的莊園，但指出在炎熱地區應面向北方，寒冷地區則應面向南方:
「…從這個方位吹來的風是Subsolanus，希臘人稱之為Apeliotes。在健康的地方，農舍和葡萄園都朝向這個方向。這風伴隨著柔和、輕盈的細雨。」4

Introduction: Vulturnus, sometimes spelled Volturnus, is the Roman god of the southeast wind, closely linked to the Greek Eurus, the god of the east or southeast wind, which is associated with dry and wet winds<sup>1</sup>. His Latin name likely derives from an Italian mountain.<sup>2</sup>

Known for his fierce temperament, Vulturnus is said to have played a dramatic role in history: at the Battle of Cannae (216 BCE), the Carthaginian general Hannibal timed his attack to coincide with this wind, which blew dust and sand into the eyes of the Roman soldiers, blinding them at a critical moment.<sup>3</sup>

Introduction: Eurus is the Greek god of the east or southeast wind and one of the four main wind gods, alongside Boreas (north), Zephyrus (west), and Notus (south). His Roman counterpart is Vulturnus<sup>1</sup>.

This wind is linked to autumn, rain, and warm weather, melting  snow on the high mountain ridges, piled there by the West Wind.<sup>2</sup> He lives near the sun god Helios’s palace in the far east, symbolizing his rule over the east wind and dawn.<sup>3</sup>

On the Tower of the Winds in Athens, Eurus is depicted as a stern old man wrapped in a mantle, holding grain and a sickle. Eurus is less well known than his siblings: Zephyr, Boreas, and Notus. However, there appears to be mention of him (as Euros) in The Odyssey, and by later authors.4

Eurus paired with Notus, the South wind, mirroring the Boreas (north wind) and Zephyrus (west wind) duo.<sup>5</sup> Eurus was said to have had a daughter Otrera, an Amazon queen who married Ares and bore Hippolyte and Penthesileia—the latter fought in the Trojan War and was killed by Achilles.<sup>6</sup>

簡介: Eurus是希臘的東風或東南風之神，為四大風神之一，與北風Boreas、西風Zephyrus及南風Notus並列。他的羅馬對應神為Vulturnus<sup>1</sup>.
此風與秋季、降雨及溫暖天氣有關，能融化高山脊上的積雪，這些積雪由西風堆積而成。<sup>2</sup>他居住在太陽神Helios宮殿附近的遠東，象徵他對東風與黎明的掌控。<sup>3</sup>
在雅典的風之塔(Tower of the Winds)上，Eurus被描繪成一位嚴肅的老人，披著披風，手持穀物與鐮刀。Eurus不如他的兄弟姊妹Zephyr、Boreas和Notus那樣知名，然而在《奧德賽》(Odyssey)中似乎有提及他（稱為Euros），並被後世作家引用。<sup>4</sup>
Eurus與南風Notus成對，對應北風Boreas與西風Zephyrus的組合。<sup>5</sup>據說Eurus有一女兒Otrera，是亞馬遜女王，嫁給戰神Ares，生下Hippolyte與Penthesileia，後者曾參與特洛伊戰爭（Trojan War），並被阿基里斯（Achilles）所殺。<sup>6</sup>

Introduction: In Roman and Greek mythology, Auster (Roman) and its counterpart Notus (Greek) represent the south wind. Both embody the hot, stormy winds of late summer and autumn that bring heavy rains and threaten to devastate crops.<sup>1</sup> In Roman mythology, the name Auster derives from the Latin word Australis, meaning “southern”. This connection extends to geography, as the name Australia — the “southern land” on the map — originates from Auster.<sup>2</sup>
The destructive power of the south wind is vividly captured in this ancient description in Ovid’s Metamorphoses, describing the Great Flood:
The Southwind flies abroad with dripping wings,
concealing in the gloom his awful face:
the drenching rain descends from his wet beard
and hoary locks; dark clouds are on his brows
and from his wings and garments drip the dews:
his great hands press the overhanging clouds;
loudly the thunders roll; the torrents pour;
…The standing grain is beaten to the ground,
the rustic's crops are scattered in the mire,
and he bewails the long year's fruitless toil.”3

The Greeks believed Notus dwelled in Ethiopia, considered the southernmost region of the known world at the time, signifying the origin of these southern storms. His arrival was often linked to the rising of Sirius, the Dog Star, heralding the onset of the searing sirocco winds that could devastate crops and bring flooding rains.<sup>4</sup>

Notus also appears in various myths as part of the collective winds. For example, in the Odyssey, Aeolus, keeper of the winds, gives Odysseus a bag containing all winds except Zephyrus; when opened, Notus and the other winds escape, blowing Odysseus’s ships off course.<sup>5</sup>

簡介: 在羅馬與希臘神話中，Auster（羅馬）及其對應的希臘神Notus代表南風。兩者皆象徵夏末和秋季的炎熱暴風，帶來大雨並威脅農作物的破壞。<sup>1</sup>羅馬神話中，Auster一名源自拉丁語Australis，意指「南方」；這一詞源也延伸至地理名稱澳大利亞（Australia），即地圖上的「南方大陸」。<sup>2</sup>
南風的破壞力在奧維德(Ovid)《變形記》(Metamorphoses)中對大洪水的描述中生動展現：
「南風展翅飛翔，
隱藏其可怖的面容於陰暗中；
濕潤的鬍鬚與灰白的髮絲滴下滂沱大雨，
烏雲覆蓋其眉頭，
露水從翅膀與衣裳滴落；
其雙手壓迫懸垂的雲層，
雷聲隆隆，洪流傾瀉；
…站立的穀物被打倒，
農夫的莊稼散落泥濘，
他哀嘆一整年徒勞的辛勤。」3
希臘人認為Notus居住於埃塞俄比亞，當時被視為已知世界最南端的地區，象徵南方風暴的起源。他的到來常與天狼星（犬星）的升起相聯繫，預示著灼熱的西洛科風（Sirocco）來襲，可能毀壞農作物並帶來洪水。<sup>4</sup>
Notus亦在多個神話中作為風神集體的一員出現。例如在《奧德賽》(Odyssey)中，風神守護者Aeolus將除西風Zephyrus外的所有風封入袋中，交給奧德修斯，但袋子被打開後，Notus與其他風逃出，將奧德修斯的船隻吹離航道。<sup>5</sup>

Introduction: In both Greek and Roman mythology, Libonotus (Greek) and Austro-Africus (Roman) represent the south-southwest wind. In the classical system of winds, Libonotus was positioned between Notus, the south wind, and Zephyrus, the west wind, Libonotus was a hot wind.<sup>1</sup>

Introduction: Euronotus, known as Phoenicias in Roman mythology, is a warm wind blowing from the south-southwest direction in both Greek and Roman traditions. It was situated between Eurus — the east or southeast wind — and Notus, the south wind.<sup>1</sup>
The early medieval scholar Bede (672/3 -735 CE) made a distinction between Euronotus and Euroauster, stating that:

“Tertius cardinalis Auster, qui et Notus, humidus calidus, atque fulmineus: huic a dextris Euroauster, calidus: a sinistris Euronotus temperatus, calidus. Venti australes quia ex humili flaut, majores in mari tempestates faciunt, quam septentrionales. Ideoque post austros fiunt noxii praecipue terrae motus.”2

Translated as: “The third cardinal wind is Auster, also known as Notus, moist and warm, and stormy; to its right is Euroauster, warm; to its left is Euronotus, temperate and warm. The southern winds, because they blow from low places, create greater storms at sea than the northern ones. Therefore, after the southern winds, particularly harmful earthquakes occur).

簡介: 歐羅諾圖斯（Euronotus），在羅馬神話中稱為腓尼基亞斯（Phoenicias），是希臘與羅馬傳統中自南南東方向吹來的溫暖之風。它位於東風或東南風歐若斯（Eurus）與南風諾圖斯（Notus）之間。<sup>1</sup>
早期中世紀學者貝德（Bede，約公元672/3–735年）區分了歐羅諾圖斯與歐羅奧斯特（Euroauster），並指出：

“Tertius cardinalis Auster, qui et Notus, humidus calidus, atque fulmineus: huic a dextris Euroauster, calidus: a sinistris Euronotus temperatus, calidus. Venti australes quia ex humili flaut, majores in mari tempestates faciunt, quam septentrionales. Ideoque post austros fiunt noxii praecipue terrae motus.”2
譯文：「第三個主風是奧斯特（Auster），亦稱諾圖斯（Notus），潮濕且溫暖，且多風暴；其右側是歐羅奧斯特，溫暖；其左側是歐羅諾圖斯，溫和且溫暖。南風因自低地吹來，於海上形成比北風更強烈的風暴。因此，南風之後，特別是會發生有害的地震。」

Table.Wind Characteristics: Puts an end to winter, bringing forth blossoms

Introduction: Favonius in Roman mythology, or Zephyrus in Greek tradition, is the gentle god of the west wind. His name derives from the Latin favere, meaning “to favor”<sup>1</sup>, aptly reflecting his nature as the mild messenger of spring and early summer breezes. This benevolent character is vividly captured by Virgil (70-19 BCE), who wrote:
“But when glad summer at the west wind [Zephyrus]'s call
Sends either flock to pasture in the glades,
Soon as the day-star shineth, hie we then
To the cool meadows, while the dawn is young,
The grass yet hoary, and to browsing herds
The dew tastes sweetest on the tender sward.”2

About 450 years later, Isidore of Seville (c 560- 636 CE) described Favonius as arriving in the spring and says it is named because it nourishes fruits and flowers, emphasizing his power to revive the earth after winter’s chill.<sup>3</sup>

According to  McCartney, Favonius was considered the “pleasantest of winds and was looked upon as a herald of spring and flowers”.<sup>4</sup> This imagery is echoed in the Tower of the Winds in Athens, where  Zephyrus (Favonius) is sculpted as a handsome, winged youth carrying flowers and fruit<sup>5</sup> — symbols of fertility and renewal — thus embodying the mildness and nurturing power of the west wind.
The warm, moist breezes of Favonius/Zephyrus were crucial to both agriculture and navigation.

“It was a seasonable wind for sailing; prayers were made to it to send breezes favorable for ships, It rose near or during the evening. It was noted for collecting and driving before it the largest clouds.”6

Despite the mildness of the wind associated with him, there were darker tales of Zephyr/Favonius. For example, the myth of Chloris tells how Favonius kidnapped this nymph — a female nature spirit in Greek mythology — and transformed her into Flora, the goddess of flowers.<sup>7</sup> Their union symbolizes the blossoming of spring, and their son Karpos’ name means “fruit”, underscoring the theme of fertility and growth.

In the tale of Hyacinthus, Zephyrus fell in love with the Spartan prince, who preferred the Apollo (or, Zephyrus’s brother, Boreas). In anger and revenge, Zephyrus caused the fatal accident that led to Hyacinthus’s death<sup>8</sup>, revealing that even the gentlest wind could be driven by envy and vengeance.

簡介: 法翁紐士（Favonius）在羅馬神話中，或稱希臘傳統中的澤菲洛斯（Zephyrus），是溫和的西風之神。他的名字源自拉丁語動詞favere，意為「偏愛」或「有利於」<sup>1</sup>，恰如其分地反映了他作為春季和初夏微風的溫和使者的本質。維吉爾(Virgil)（公元前70–19年）生動地描繪了他的形象：
「但當愉悅的夏天應西風(澤菲洛斯)之召，
將任一群羊送往林間空地放牧，
牧群便在林間草地放牧，
旭日初升時，我們便匆匆前往涼爽的草地，
晨曦初露，草葉尚帶霜華，
露水在嫩草上最為甘甜，牧群正好啃食。」2
約四百五十年後，塞維利亞的伊西多爾(Isidore of Seville)（約公元560–636年）描述法翁紐士於春季到來，並指出其名稱源於滋養果實和花朵，強調他在冬季寒冷過後復甦大地的力量。<sup>3</sup>
根據McCartney的說法，法翁紐士被視為「最宜人的風，並被看作春天與花朵的使者」。<sup>4</sup> 這一形象在雅典的風之塔(Tower of the Winds)中得以呼應，澤菲洛斯（法翁紐士）被雕塑成一位英俊的有翼青年，手持花果<sup>5</sup> —— 象徵生育與再生，體現了西風的溫和與滋養力量。
法翁紐士／澤菲洛斯帶來的溫暖濕潤微風對農業與航海都至關重要。
「這是適合航行的季節風；人們向它祈禱，祈求送來有利於船隻的微風；它常在傍晚或傍晚前升起；以其力量聚集並驅趕最大的雲團。」6
儘管與他相關的風溫和，但澤菲洛斯／法翁紐士也有較為陰暗的傳說。例如，神話中春天女神克洛里斯（Chloris）被法翁紐士綁架，並被他化身為花神弗洛拉（Flora）。<sup>7</sup> 他們的結合象徵春天的綻放，他們的兒子卡爾波斯（Karpos）意為「果實」，強調了生育與成長的主題。
在海辛斯（Hyacinthus）的故事中，澤菲洛斯愛上了斯巴達王子海辛斯，但王子偏愛阿波羅(Apollo)（或澤菲洛斯的兄弟波瑞阿斯[Boreas]）。出於嫉妒和報復，澤菲洛斯導致了海辛斯的致命事故<sup>8</sup>， 顯示即使是最溫柔的風也可能被嫉妒與復仇驅使。

Introduction: Africus, known as Lips in Greek mythology, personifies the southwest wind. The Roman name Africus derives from the province of Africa, reflecting the wind’s origin in the southwest and its association with the African coastline<sup>1</sup>. This etymological connection illustrates how the ancients linked meteorological phenomena with geographic regions, embodying natural forces in culturally significant ways.

This association is vividly represented on the Tower of the Winds in Athens, Greece, where Lips (Africus) is sculpted as a youthful figure grasping the stern of a ship<sup>2</sup>, symbolizing his dominion over the southwest maritime winds essential for navigation across the Mediterranean.

Although Lips and Africus lack extensive individual mythological narratives, their influence is attested in classical literature and local customs. The geographer Pausanias (c. 110-c 180 CE), in his Description of Greece, recorded how when visiting Methana (a town in Greece) he saw farmers made a sacrifice to preserve their vines from this fierce wind.

“The wind called Lips, striking the budding vines from the Saronic Gulf, blights their buds. So while the wind is still rushing on, two men cut in two a cock whose feathers are all white, and run round the vines in opposite directions, each carrying half of the cock. When they meet at their starting place, they bury the pieces there. Such are the means they have devised against the Lips.”3

This passage exemplifies the ancients’ perception of Lips/Africus as a powerful and ambivalent force, capable of causing agricultural harm yet also integral to the natural and economic rhythms of Mediterranean life.

簡介: 阿弗里庫斯（Africus），在希臘神話中稱為利普斯（Lips），象徵西南風。羅馬名稱「阿弗里庫斯」源自非洲行省，反映該風來自西南方，並與非洲海岸線相關聯<sup>1</sup>。這一詞源關係展現了古人如何將氣象現象與地理區域聯繫起來，以文化意義的方式體現自然力量。
這種聯繫在希臘雅典的風之塔(Tower of the Winds)上有生動的呈現，利普斯（阿弗里庫斯）被雕塑成一位年輕人物，緊握船尾<sup>2</sup>，象徵他對西南海風的主宰，這些海風對地中海航行至關重要。
儘管利普斯與阿弗里庫斯在神話中缺乏詳細的個別故事，但他們的影響在古典文學與地方習俗中有所體現。地理學家保撒尼亞斯(Pausanias)（約公元110年至180年）在其《希臘志》(Description of Greece)中記錄了他訪問希臘梅塔納(Methana)鎮時，看到農民為了保護葡萄藤免受這股猛烈風害而進行祭祀的情況。
「名為利普斯的風，從薩羅尼克灣(Saronic Gulf)吹來，打落葡萄藤的嫩芽。因此，當風仍在呼嘯時，兩人將一隻全白羽毛的公雞劈成兩半，分別帶著雞的一半，朝相反方向繞著葡萄藤奔跑。當他們回到起點時，便將雞的兩半埋在那裡。他們就是用這種方法對抗利普斯。」3
此段文字展現了古人對利普斯／阿弗里庫斯的認知：這是一股強大且矛盾的力量，既能對農業造成損害，又是地中海自然與經濟節奏中不可或缺的一部分。

Introduction: The Roman poet Lucan (39-65 CE), in his Pharsalia, called Corus “darkener of the eastern sky”, highlighting its role in tempestuous weather.<sup>1</sup> Corus, (also sometimes called  Caurus) was associated with a northwest wind. It appears to have been the Roman counterpart for the Greek minor wind, Skiron<sup>2</sup>, or Argestes. But, as early as Strabo (64/63 BCE – 24 CE), writers were unclear on who called which wind what.

“But Posidonius remarks that none of those who are really acquainted with these subjects, such as Aristotle, Timosthenes, and Bion the astronomer, entertain so mistaken an opinion in regard to the winds. They say that the north-east (Cæcias) blows from the commencement of summer, and that the southwest wind (Libs), which is exactly opposite to this, blows from the decline of winter. And again, the south-east wind (Eurus), which is opposite to the north-west wind (Argestes), from the commencement of winter. The east and west winds being intermediate.”3
Yet, later in his Geography, Strabo writes: “The wind Argestes, which blows from the left with violence, from these summits is called by the Athenians Sciron”.<sup>4</sup>

Authors after Strabo continued be unclear whether Caurus/Corus was similar to Argestes and as to its nature: gentle or fierce, bringing dry air, or hail.<sup>5</sup> Thus, we see can see it is common for tales told across millennia to be inconsistent.

簡介: 羅馬詩人盧坎（Lucan，公元39–65年）在其著作《法薩利亞戰記》（Pharsalia）中稱科魯斯為「東方天空的暗影」，突顯其在暴風雨中的角色。<sup>1</sup>科魯斯（Corus）（有時也稱為考魯斯[Caurus]）與西北風相關聯。它似乎是希臘小風神斯基隆（Skiron）<sup>2</sup>或阿爾格斯特斯（Argestes）的羅馬對應風神。但早在斯特拉波（Strabo，公元前64/63年至公元24年）時代，作家們對於誰稱呼哪股風為何名仍不甚明確。
「但波西多尼烏斯（Posidonius）指出，真正熟悉這些事物的人，如亞里士多德(Aristotle)、提莫斯塞涅斯(Timosthenes)和天文學家比翁(Bion)，並不持有如此錯誤的風向觀念。他們說東北風（Cæcias）自夏季開始吹起，與之正對的西南風（Libs）則自冬季末吹起；而東南風（Eurus）與西北風（Argestes）相對，則自冬季開始吹起。東風和西風則居中間位置。」3
然而，斯特拉波在其《地理學》(Geography)中又寫道：「阿爾格斯特斯風，從左側猛烈吹來，雅典人稱之為斯基隆（Sciron）」。<sup>4</sup>
斯特拉波之後的作者仍不清楚考魯斯／科魯斯是否與阿爾格斯特斯相似，以及其性質：是溫和還是猛烈，帶來乾燥空氣或冰雹。<sup>5</sup>因此，我們可以看到，跨越千年的傳說往往存在不一致之處。

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle, there is an illustration of a -six-armed person. In the accompanying text, in translation is states, “In the histories of Alexander the Great one reads of people in India who have six hands.”1 This may relate to the many “fantastical stories of Alexander [356-323 BCE], retold by historians, scientists and travelers, [that] inspired others to fill in the gaps of the king’s life, wondering what he may have said or written in particular situations.”2.

Among these was a novel/story that first appeared around 338 AD (about 700 years after Alexander’s death) and was copied, translated and told all in many languages across the globe for over 1,000 years<sup>3</sup>. In this English translation<sup>4</sup>, it has Alexander describing somewhere past the “Caspian Gates” where he and his army pitched camp near a lake and that night saw:

“…wild boars that were larger than the lion, and the tusks of each of which were a cubit long; we saw too wolves and leopards and panthers and beasts with scorpions' tails, and elephants, and wild bulls, and ox-elephants, and men with six hands apiece ; and we saw men with twisted legs and teeth like dogs and faces like women.”

That story, in turn may be related to the Gegenees are described in the ancient poem The Argonautica5, as a tribe of six-armed giants who fought the Argonauts (a band of heroes in Greek mythology, led by Jason, who quested for the Golden Fleece , which symbolizes wealth and power.), on Bear Mountain in the Kapıdağ Peninsula of Mysia.

Selections of the battle between Jason and the Argonauts and the six-armed monsters in the Argonauts:

“There is a lofty island inside the Propontis , a short distance from the Phrygian mainland with its rich cornfields, sloping to the sea, where an isthmus in front of the mainland is flooded by the waves, so low does it lie. …and the inhabitants round about call the island the Mount of Bears. And insolent and fierce men dwell there, Earthborn, a great marvel to the neighbours to behold; for each one has six mighty hands to lift up, two from his sturdy shoulders, and four below, fitting close to his terrible sides.”

“About the isthmus and the plain, the Doliones had their dwelling, ... But these Earthborn monsters, ... did not harry the Doliones, owing to the protection of Poseidon ; ... Thither Argo pressed on, ... …the Earthborn men on the other side rushed down from the mountain and with crags below blocked up the mouth of vast Chytus towards the sea, like men lying in wait for a wild beast within.

But there Heracles had been left behind with the younger heroes, and he quickly bent his back-springing bow against the monsters and brought them to earth one after another; and they in their turn raised huge, ragged rocks and hurled them. For these dread monsters too [were nurtured by], the goddess Hera, bride of Zeus… to be a trial for Heracles.

“And therewithal came the rest of the martial heroes returning to meet the foe before they reached the height of outlook, and they fell to the slaughter of the Earthborn, receiving them with arrows and spears until they slew them all as they rushed fiercely to battle. And as when woodcutters cast in rows upon the beach long trees just hewn down by their axes, in order that, once sodden with brine, they may receive the strong bolts; so these monsters at the entrance of the foam-fringed harbor lay stretched one after another, some in heaps bending their heads and breasts into the salt waves with their limbs spread out above on the land; others again were resting their heads on the sand of the shore and their feet in the deep water, both alike a prey to birds and fishes at once.”
So, we can see that stories of six handed or six-armed people were popular for millennia as people imagined places of adventures far away.

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）中，有一幅描繪六臂人（Gegenees）的插圖。隨附的文字翻譯中寫道：「在亞歷山大大帝的歷史中，記載了印度有六隻手的人。」<sup>1</sup>這可能與許多關於亞歷山大大帝（Alexander the Great）（公元前356-323年）的奇幻故事有關，這些故事由歷史學家、科學家和旅行者轉述，激發他人填補國王生活中的空白，猜想他在特定情況下可能說過或寫過什麼。<sup>2</sup>
其中有一個小說／故事首次出現在公元338年左右（約在亞歷山大逝世700年後），並被複製、翻譯成多種語言，在全球流傳超過一千年<sup>3</sup>。在這個英文翻譯中<sup>4</sup>，亞歷山大描述他和軍隊在「裏海門」（Capsian Gates）以南某地紮營，當晚看見：
「……比獅子還大的野豬，每隻的獠牙長達一肘；我們還看見狼、豹、黑豹和帶蠍子尾巴的野獸、大象、野牛、牛象、每人有六隻手的人；還有腿扭曲、牙齒像狗、臉像女人的人。」
這個故事可能與古詩《阿爾戈英雄記》（The Argonautica） 5中描述的六臂巨人族群六臂人有關，他們在密西亞卡皮達格半島 的熊山（Bear Mountain）與阿爾戈英雄（the Argonauts）（希臘神話中由傑森領導尋找金羊毛的英雄隊伍）戰鬥。

「在普羅彭蒂斯海（Propontis） 內有一座高聳的島嶼，離弗里吉亞（Phrygian mainland ）富饒的穀地不遠，島前有一狹長地峽被海浪淹沒，島民稱之為熊山。那裡居住著傲慢兇猛的地生人，鄰居們驚異地看著他們；因為每人有六隻強壯的手臂，兩隻從堅實的肩膀長出，四隻貼近可怕的身側。」
「地峽和平原周圍是多利安人（Doliones） 的居所……但這些地生怪物沒有騷擾多利安人，因為波塞冬（Poseidon） 的保護……阿爾戈號 繼續前進……地生人從山上衝下，用岩石堵住通往海洋的巨大奇圖斯口，像野獸埋伏。」
「赫拉克勒斯（Heracles）被留在後方與年輕英雄們一起，他迅速拉弓射擊怪物，一個接一個將其擊倒；怪物們則舉起巨石反擊。這些可怕的怪物也是由宙斯的新娘赫拉（Hera）女神培育，成為赫拉克勒斯的考驗。」
「隨後其他戰士返回，在敵人抵達瞭望高地前迎戰，箭矢和矛刺殺地生人，直到全部擊斃。就像伐木工人在海灘上排放剛砍下的長木頭，讓它們吸鹽水以承受強弩一樣，這些怪物在泡沫環繞的海港入口處一個接一個倒下，有的頭胸彎入鹹水中，四肢攤開在陸地上；有的頭枕沙灘，腳踏深水，成為鳥魚的獵物。」
由此可見，六臂或六手人的故事在千百年來一直流行，人們憑想像描繪遠方的奇異冒險。

補充説明.裏海門: 裏海門（Caspian Gate）是位於裏海（Caspian Sea）以南的一個重要山口。裏海是世界上最大的內陸水體，位於歐亞大陸之間——歷史上用於阻擋來自北方的入侵。
補充説明.密西亞卡皮達格半島: 卡皮達格半島（Kapıdağ Peninsula of Mysia）位於現今土耳其的小亞細亞西北部地區。
補充説明.金羊毛: 金羊毛是希臘神話中著名的故事物品。它是魔法公羊身上金色的蓬鬆毛皮。
補充説明.普羅彭蒂斯海（The Propontis）: 普羅彭蒂斯海（The Propontis），或稱馬爾馬拉海（Sea of Marmara），位於土耳其西北部。它連接黑海（Black Sea）與愛琴海（Aegean Sea），位於歐洲與亞洲之間。普羅彭蒂斯是船隻在這兩海之間航行的重要通道。
補充説明.多利安人（The Doliones）: 多利安人（The Doliones）是古希臘作家羅德斯的阿波羅尼奧斯所著《阿爾戈英雄記》中的虛構部落。該部落居住在靠近土耳其馬爾馬拉海的基齊庫斯附近。他們對阿爾戈英雄和他們的領袖傑森非常友好和熱情。不幸的是，多利安人最終在夜間被阿爾戈英雄誤殺。
補充説明.波塞冬（Poseidon）: 波塞冬（Poseidon）是古希臘神話中的海神，同時也是地震和馬匹之神。他是十二奧林匹斯神之一，常被描繪成手持三叉戟的形象。
補充説明.阿爾戈號（The Argo）: 阿爾戈號（The Argo）是希臘神話中著名的船隻，載著阿爾戈英雄隊及其領袖傑森，前往黑海東端古地科爾喀斯尋回一件寶物。該地區位於現今喬治亞附近。

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle1, the Gorgades are vividly depicted as women entirely covered in hair.

One of the most famous ancient references to these creatures comes from Pliny the Elder’s Natural History (Book 6, sections 142-220)2. In English translation, Pliny calls them as “Gorgons”, likely distinct from the three snake-haired sisters of Greek mythology. These Gorgons inhabit the “Gorgades” islands, located off Africa’s northwestern coast near Mauretania.
Modern scholarship identifies the “Gorgades” with today’s Cape Verde Islands, which were still labeled “Gorgades” on a 1718 map by Dutch cartographer Gerard Valck<sup>3</sup>.
./images/staticPage/M02_page_1.png

Figure 1: Modern map of the Cape Verde Islands (left), sourced from Nations Online Project (n.d.), alongside a historical depiction of the islands from Dutch cartographer Gerard Valck in Valck’s 1718 map (right).
Pliny writes:

“An island opposite the Persian Gulf and lying off Ethiopia is named Cerne; neither its size nor its distance from the mainland has been ascertained, but it is reported to be inhabited solely by Ethiopian tribes. [199] Ephorus states that vessels approaching it from the Red Sea are unable became of the heat to advance beyond the Columns - that being the name of certain small islands. Polybius informs us that Cerne lies at the extremity of Mauretania, over against Mount Atlas, a mile from the coast; Cornelius Nepos gives it as being nearly in the same meridian as Carthage, and 10 miles from the mainland, and as measuring not more than 2 miles round. There is also reported to be another island off Mount Atlas, itself also called Atlantis, from which a two days' voyage along the coast reaches the desert district in the neighborhood of the Western Ethiopians and the cape mentioned above named the Horn of the West, the point at which the coastline begins to curve westward in the direction of the Atlantic.

Opposite this cape also there are reported to be some islands, the Gorgades, which some thought were formerly the habitation of the Gorgons, and which according to the account of Xenophon of Lampsacus are at a distance of two days' sail from the mainland. These islands were reached by the Carthaginian general Hanno, a who reported that the women had hair all over their bodies, but that the men were so swift of foot that they got away.”
Pomponius Mela (c. 43 CE) offers a strikingly vivid portrait of the Gorgades as wild, feral women living apart from men:

“Beyond them a great bend of the shore incloses a huge island, on which they say there are only women, bristly in their whole body, and fruitful of their own accord without any connections with males: of so savage and excessively wild manners that some of them can scarcely be restrained by chains from struggling.”
French theologian Pierre d’Ailly echoes this image in his 15th-century Imago Mundi, as noted by Wiesner-Hanks (2014):

“Pierre d’Ailly repeats Pliny’s story in his Imago Mundi, an encyclopedic account of the inhabitants of the world written in the fifteenth century: “The Gorgodes Islands of the ocean… are inhabited by the Gorgodes, women of destructiveness, with coarse and hairy bodies.”Columbus had d’Ailly’s book as well as Pliny’s in his sea chest on his first voyage, although he does not seem to be as keen on finding Gorgades as he is on finding Amazons. (Amazons were thought to be muscular, but not hairy.)”

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》<sup>1</sup>（Nuremberg Chronicle）中，Gorgades被描繪為全身長滿毛髮的女性。附帶的文字寫著：「多毛的女性，坐著並比劃著手勢。」
其中一個最著名的古代記載來自古羅馬學者老普林尼（Pliny the Elder）的《自然史》<sup>2</sup>（Natural History）（第6卷，第142-220節）。普林尼稱她們為「Gorgons」，可能與希臘神話中三位蛇髮女妖不同。這些Gorgons居住在非洲西北海岸附近的「Gorgades」群島上。
現代學者認為「Gorgades」即今天的佛得角群島（Cape Verde），1718年荷蘭製圖師Gerard Valck的地圖<sup>3</sup>上仍標示為「Gorgades」。
./images/staticPage/M02_page_1.png
圖1：佛得角群島的現代地圖（左），資料來源為Nations Online Project（無日期），旁為荷蘭製圖師Gerard Valck於1718年繪製的歷史島嶼圖（右）。
普林尼寫道：
「在波斯灣(Persian Gulf)對面，位於埃塞俄比亞外海有一島名為Cerne；其大小與距離大陸尚未確定，但據說僅由埃塞俄比亞部落居住。……在這個海角對面也有幾個島嶼，稱為Gorgades，過去是Gorgons的居所，據Lampsacus的Xenophon所述，距離大陸兩天船程。迦太基將軍Hanno曾抵達這些島嶼，報告說那裡的女性全身長滿毛髮，但男性腳步極快，能逃走。」
古羅馬地理學家Pomponius Mela（約公元43年）生動描繪Gorgades為與男性分離、野性凶猛的女性：
「在她們之外，有一個巨大的海岸彎曲包圍著一個巨大島嶼，據說島上只有女性，身體長滿刺毛，且能自行繁殖，無需與男性接觸；她們性情野蠻，極難被鎖鏈束縛。」4
15世紀法國神學家Pierre d’Ailly在其《世界圖像》 （Imago Mundi）中也重述了這一形象：
「海洋中的Gorgodes群島……居住著破壞性強、體毛粗糙的Gorgodes女性。」意大利遞海家哥倫布(Christopher Columbus)首次航行時攜帶了d’Ailly和普林尼的著作，儘管他對尋找Gorgades的興趣不及尋找亞馬遜女戰士（亞馬遜被認為肌肉發達但不多毛）。

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle, after describing that in “the histories of Alexander” some people in India have six hands, it goes on to say: “Item: Some are naked and rough and live in the water; some have six digits on hands and feet.”1

Having extra fingers and toes has been shown to be revered among the Chaco people in what is now New Mexico and among the Mayan cultures<sup>2</sup> however, those cultures were not in contact with Europe and the author and illustrator of the Nuremberg Chronicle. In Sicily, extra fingers were associated with bad luck, whereas in Malta it was seen as a freak of nature, or sometimes said “generally believed by many, to be a freak transmission of a genetical trait of that ‘antediluvian race of giants’ mentioned in the book of Genesis in the Bible and the Apocrypha”.<sup>3</sup>

This description aligns with folk-conception of Nephilim as a race of giants, maybe the children of angels or fallen angels<sup>4</sup>. At the same time, there is also a mention of a six-fingered giant in  Samuel 21:20 in the Bible (English Standard Version, 2001):
“In still another battle, which took place at Gath, there was a huge man with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four in all. He also was descended from Rapha.”
Then, in Numbers 13:32-33:

“So they brought to the people of Israel a bad report of the land that they had spied out, saying, “The land, through which we have gone to spy it out, is a land that devours its inhabitants, and all the people that we saw in it are of great height. And there we saw the Nephilim (the sons of Anak, who come from the Nephilim), and we seemed to ourselves like grasshoppers, and so we seemed to them.”5
Canaan:

Canaan as an area has been defined in different ways across thousands of years, but usually centered on Palestine.<sup>6</sup> So the students doing this project chose to identify the six-fingered person in the illustration as a Nephilim, and chose to locate them in Palestine.

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）中，描述「亞歷山大歷史」（The histories of Alexander）中印度有人擁有六隻手，並接著說：「有些人赤裸且粗糙，生活在水中；有些人的手和腳各有六根指頭。」<sup>1</sup>
在現在的新墨西哥州查科（Chaco）地區的查科人和瑪雅文化中，擁有多餘的手指和腳趾被視為受尊崇的特徵（Sidder, 2016）2，但這些文化與歐洲及《紐倫堡編年史》的作者和插畫家並無接觸。在西西里島，多餘的手指被認為是不幸的象徵，而在馬耳他則被視為自然異象，有時被普遍認為是《聖經·創世記》和《次經》中提及的「遠古巨人種族」的遺傳特徵3。
這一描述與民間對拿非利人作為巨人種族的概念相符，他們可能是天使或墮落天使的後代<sup>4</sup>。同時，《聖經·撒母耳記下》21:20也提及過一位六指巨人（英語標準版，2001）：
「在迦特的另一場戰鬥中，有一個巨人，雙手各有六根手指，雙腳各有六根腳趾，共二十四根。他也是拉法族的後裔。」
「他們向以色列人報告說：『我們所窺探的那地，是吞滅居民之地，我們所見的百姓個個身材高大。我們在那裏看見了拿非利人（亞拿族的子孫，他們本是拿非利人的後裔），我們自己在他們眼中好像蚱蜢一樣，他們在我們眼中也是如此。』」5
迦南：
迦南地區在數千年來有不同的定義，但通常以巴勒斯坦為中心<sup>6</sup>。因此，參與此專案的學生選擇將插圖中六指的人物識別為拿非利人，並將其定位於巴勒斯坦。

補充説明.拉法族: 拉法（Rapha）是聖經中提及的一個人物，特別是在拿非利人（Nephilim）和古代巨人族的背景下。他被描述為巨人的後裔，並與高大威猛的身材和力量相關聯。拉法一詞與「利乏音」（Rephaim）密切相關，後者指的是一群生活在約旦河以東的巨人族，巴珊王噩（Og）即是其中之一。聖經中多處提及拉法及其後裔，顯示他們在古代歷史和傳說中具有重要地位。

Table.Physical Characteristics: Half-human, half-horse (or donkey) but shown with only two feet

Introduction: In the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle it states: “Item: In Scythia are people with hoofs like a horse.”1
Tales of Centaurs (half horse and half human) have been told at least as far back as the myths of Theseus and Achilles<sup>2</sup>.
The Roman naturalist Pliny the Elder (25-97 CE) in book 7, section 35 of his Natural History reported:
“Claudius Caesar writes that a hippo-centaur was born in Thessaly and died the same day; and in his reign we actually saw one that was brought here for him from Egypt preserved in honey.”3
This suggests that people were fascinated enough by the creature to preserve and display something like one, blurring the line between myth and reality.

Roman writer Claudius Aelianus (~ 175–235 CE) wrote about centaurs in his book De Natura Animalium (Book 17, Chapter 9), in this English translation he writes that he cannot say how such beings came to be, or whether they are just rumour, but that he has heard them described.

“There is a certain creature which they call an Onocentaura and anybody who has seen one would never have doubted that the race of Centaurs once existed, and that artificers did not falsify Nature, but that time produced even these creatures by blending dissimilar bodies into one. But whether, in fact they came into being and visited us at one and the same period, or whether rumour; more ductile than any wax and too credulous, fashioned, them and by some miraculous combination fused the halves of a horse and a man while endowing them with a single soul — let us pass them by. But this creature of which my discourse set out to speak, I have heard described as follows. 'Its face is like that of a man and is surrounded by thick hair. Its neck below its face, and its chest are also those of a man, but its teats are swelling and stand out on the breast; its shoulders, arms, and forearms, its hands too . . . chest down to the waist are also those of a man. But its spine, ribs, belly, and hind legs closely resemble those of an ass; likewise its colour is ashen, although beneath the flanks it inclines to white. The hands of this creature serve a double purpose, for when speed is necessary they run in front of the hind legs, and it can move quite as fast as other quadrupeds. Again, if it needs to pluck something, or to put it down, or to seize and hold it tight, what were feet become hands; it no longer walks but sits down. The creature has a violent temper. At any rate if captured it will not endure servitude and in its yearning for freedom' declines all food and dies of starvation.”4

This shows the Onocentaur as not just a curious animal but a wild spirit that refuses to be tamed. The story doesn’t stop with there. In the 4th century CE, the Christian theologian Athanasius of Alexandria (293-373 CE) describes a similar being in his Life of Antony. Though he doesn’t call it an Onocentaur, his description of a demonic creature, which the Egyptian Christian monk St. Anthony dismissed in the desert, seems similar.:

“ A few days after, as he was working (for he was careful to work hard), some one stood at the door and pulled the plait which he was working, for he used to weave baskets…And rising up he saw a beast like a man to the thighs but having legs and feet like those of an ass. And Antony only signed himself and said, 'I am a servant of Christ. If thou art sent against me, behold I am here.' But the beast together with his evil spirits fled, so that, through his speed, he fell and died.”5

This shows how the image of the half-man, half-donkey creature travelled through different cultures and stories, even appearing in early Christian writings. It may have also affected depictions of the devil which shows him with hooves.

The term Onocentaur also appears in a version of the Bible. In Isaiah 34:14, the Latin Vulgate uses the word “onocentauris” to translate some unclear Hebrew words that describe desert or evil spirits:
“Et occurrent daemonia onocentauris, et pilosus clamabit alter ad alterum; ibi cubavit lamia, et invenit sibi requiem.”6
In the King James Bible (17th century version), this verse is translated as:
“The wild beasts of the desert shall also meet with the wild beasts of the island, and the satyr shall cry to his fellow; the screech owl also shall rest there and find for herself a place of rest.”7

Here, the Onocentauris become “satyrs,” creatures from Greek mythology known for being wild and strange. This shows how translators used the idea of the Onocentaur to explain mysterious words in the Bible, linking it to a sense of the wild and unknown.
However, in the more newly revised King James edition, the verse is translated thus:
“The wild beasts of the desert shall also meet with the jackals, And the wild goat shall bleat to its companion; Also the night creature shall rest there, And find for herself a place of rest.

From ancient Roman writings to Christian scripture, the Onocentaur remains a powerful symbol of the strange mix between human and animal, civilization and wilderness, order and chaos. Its story reminds us how myths grow and change, blending fact and fiction to capture our imagination.

Table.身體特徵: 半人半馬（或驢），但只有兩隻腳

簡介: 《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）英文譯本中記載：「項目：在斯基泰（Scythia）有些人長著像馬蹄的蹄子。」<sup>1</sup>
關於半人馬（半馬半人）的傳說至少可以追溯到忒修斯（Theseus）和阿基里斯（Achilles）的神話時代。<sup>2</sup>
羅馬博物學家老普林尼（Pliny the Elder）（公元25-97年）在其《自然史》（Natural History）第七卷第35節中寫道：
「克勞狄烏斯·凱撒（Claudius Caesar）寫道，色薩利（Thessaly）曾出生一隻半馬半人的生物，當天即死；在他統治期間，我們實際見過一隻從埃及帶來的，浸泡在蜂蜜中保存的此類生物。」3
這表明人們對這種生物充滿好奇，甚至將其保存展示，模糊了神話與現實的界限。
古羅馬作家克勞狄烏斯·艾利安努斯（Claudius Aelianus）（約公元175–235年）在其著作《動物的本性》（De Natura Animalium）（第17卷第9章）中談及半人馬，英文譯本中他表示不確定這類生物如何產生，或是否僅是謠言，但他曾聽聞相關描述：

「有一種生物稱為Onocentaura，任何見過它的人都不會懷疑半人馬族曾經存在，工匠們並非偽造自然，而是時間孕育了這些由不同身體融合而成的生物，賦予它們單一靈魂。但它們是否真的存在並同時造訪我們，或是謠言——比蠟更易塑形且過於輕信，通過奇蹟般的組合將馬與人半身融合——讓我們暫且不論。關於我所述的這種生物，我聽聞的描述如下：『其面如人，周圍覆蓋濃密毛髮。面下的頸部與胸膛也是人形，但乳房隆起突出；肩膀、手臂、前臂和手……從胸部到腰部均為人形。但脊椎、肋骨、腹部及後腿則酷似驢，顏色呈灰白，腹側偏白。此生物的手有雙重用途，當需快速移動時，手在後腿前方奔跑，速度可與四足動物媲美。若需摘取、放下或緊握物品，手即成為腳，不再行走而坐下。此生物性情暴躁，若被捕獲則拒絕服從，渴望自由，拒絕進食最終餓死。』」4
這顯示Onocentaur不僅是奇特動物，更是拒絕馴服的野性靈魂。故事並未止步於此。公元4世紀，亞歷山大港基督教神學家亞他那修（Athanasius of Alexandria）（293-373年）在《安東尼的生平》（Life of Antony）中描述了類似生物。雖未稱其為Onocentaur，但他描述埃及基督教修士聖安東尼（St. Anthony）在曠野驅逐的惡魔似乎相似：
「數日後，當他努力工作時（他勤奮工作），有人站在門口拉扯他編織的籃子辮子……他起身見一生物，從大腿以上似人，下肢與腳如驢。安東尼只自我簽名並說：『我是基督的僕人，若你被差遣來攻擊我，我就在這裡。』惡獸與其邪靈遂逃離，因奔跑過快而跌倒死去。」5
此描述顯示半人半驢的形象穿越不同文化與故事，甚至出現在早期基督教著作中，可能也影響了魔鬼形象中帶蹄的描繪。
Onocentaur一詞亦出現在聖經版本中。以賽亞書34:14拉丁文武加大譯本使用「onocentauris」翻譯一些不明確的希伯來詞，描述荒野或邪靈：
「Et occurrent daemonia onocentauris, et pilosus clamabit alter ad alterum; ibi cubavit lamia, et invenit sibi requiem. 」6
在17世紀的《欽定版聖經》中，此節譯為：
「曠野的野獸必與島上的野獸相遇，撒旦向同伴呼喊；貓頭鷹也在那裡安歇，尋得安息之所。」
此處Onocentauris被譯為「撒旦」（satyrs），源自希臘神話中野性怪異的生物，顯示翻譯者用Onocentaur的概念解釋聖經中神秘詞彙，連結荒野與未知之意。
然而，在較新的《欽定版修訂版》中，此節譯為：
「曠野的野獸必與豺狼相遇，野山羊向同伴咩叫；夜行生物也在那裡安歇，尋得安息之所。」7
從古羅馬文獻到基督教經文，Onocentaur始終是人與獸、文明與荒野、秩序與混沌奇異融合的強烈象徵。其故事提醒我們，神話如何在事實與虛構間演變，激發想像力。

補充説明.斯基泰: 斯基泰（Scythia）是古希臘羅馬世界中定義的一個地理區域，主要涵蓋位於黑海北部的頓巴斯草原地區。
補充説明.色薩利: 色薩利（Thessaly）位於希臘北部愛琴海畔（Aegean Sea），是被山脈環繞的肥沃平原，以農業和畜牧業聞名，包含拉里薩（Larissa）與沃洛斯（Volos）等城市，歷史上為古希臘重要地區。

Table.Name: Machlyes
Table.Body Characteristics: Hermaphrodites (with both male and female features)

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle, the following descriptions could match the image above, in a section after the mention of “in the histories of Alexander” and descriptions of peoples in India, it states:
“Women with beards extending down to their breasts, but their heads hairless and bald.”
However, the illustration may also relate to text earlier on that page:
“In Lybia ... Some are double-sexed, the right breast male, the left one female. They are indiscriminate in their associations with one another and bear children.”1
So, does that mean that the headless with mouths and eyes are “double-sexed” or that in Libya there are double-sexed people?

The students working on this project decided that they believed that this illustration relates to a legendary tribe called the Machyles and said to inhabit Libya. According to Wikipedia, a French anthropologist Lucien Bertholon hypothesized that the Maghrawa tribal confederation of Tunisia might be descendants of the Machlyes.<sup>2</sup>
Herodotus (c. 430 BC) describes them in The Histories 4.180.1 as follows:

“[On the tribes of Libya:] Next to the Makhlyes (Machlyes) are the Auseans; these and the Makhlyes, separated by the Triton, live on the shores of Lake Tritonis. The Makhlyes wear their hair long behind, the Auseans in front. They celebrate a yearly festival of Athena, where their maidens are separated into two bands and fight each other with stones and sticks, thus, they say, honoring in the way of their ancestors that native goddess whom we call Athena. Maidens who die of their wounds are called false virgins. Before the girls are set fighting, the whole people choose the fairest maid, and arm her with a Korinthian (Corinthian) helmet and Greek panoply, to be then mounted on a chariot and drawn all along the lake shore. With what armor they equipped their maidens before Greeks came to live near them, I cannot say; but I suppose the armor was Egyptian; for I maintain that the Greeks took their shield and helmet from Egypt.”3
The Roman writer Pliny the Elder also mentions the Machlyes in Natural History 7.15:

“Beyond the Nasamones [of Libya] and adjacent to them Calliphanes records the Machlyes, who are androgynous and perform the function of either sex alternatively. Aristotle [Greek philosopher C4th B.C.] adds that their left breast is that of a man and their right breast that of a woman.”4

They were said to inhabit a region in Africa that lay outside the Egyptian Empire, around a great river called the Triton, which emptied into a large lake known as Lake Tritonis. At this moment there is no strong consensus on its corresponding modern location, maybe Siwa Oasis in Egypt, maybe Chott El Jerid (a large Salt Lake in Tunisa).<sup>5, 6</sup>

Table.身體特徵: 雌雄同體（具有男性和女性特徵）

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》(Nuremberg Chronicle)中，以下描述可能與上述圖片相符，在提及「亞歷山大歷史」 (The History of Alexander)及印度民族描述之後的一節中，記載：
「婦女有鬍鬚垂至胸部，但頭部無毛且禿頂。」
然而，插圖也可能與該頁較早的文字有關：
「在利比亞……有些是雙性，右胸為男性，左胸為女性。他們彼此之間無差別地交往，並能生育子女。」1
那麼，這是否意味著那些沒有頭但有嘴和眼睛的，是「雙性」？或者說利比亞有雙性人？
參與此專案的學生們認為，這幅插圖與一個傳說中的部族Machlyes有關，據說他們居住在利比亞。根據維基百科，法國人類學家盧西恩·貝爾托隆（Lucien Bertholon）假設突尼西亞的馬格拉瓦部族(Maghrawa)聯盟可能是Machlyes的後裔。<sup>2</sup>
希羅多德(Herodotus)（1920年）在《歷史》(The Histories)4.180.1中描述他們如下：

「緊鄰Makhlyes（Machlyes）的是Auseans；這兩族由特里同河(Triton River)分隔，居住在特里同湖岸邊。Machlyes後髮長，Auseans前髮長。他們每年舉行雅典娜節，少女分成兩隊用石頭和棍棒互相搏鬥，以此方式祭祀他們祖先的本土女神，我們稱之為雅典娜（Athena）。受傷致死的少女被稱為假處女。戰鬥開始前，族人選出最美的少女，為她配戴科林斯頭盔和希臘盔甲，然後乘戰車沿湖岸遊行。希臘人來此之前，她們用什麼盔甲我不得而知，但我猜是埃及盔甲，因為我認為希臘人的盾牌和頭盔源自埃及。」3
羅馬作家老普林尼(Pliny the Elder)在《博物志》(Natural History)7.15也提及Machlyes：
「在納薩蒙人(Nasamones)（利比亞）之外，卡利法尼斯(Calliphanes)記錄了Machlyes，他們是雌雄同體，交替扮演男女角色。亞里士多德(Aristotle)補充說，他們左胸為男性，右胸為女性。」4
據說他們居住在非洲一處埃及帝國之外的地區，環繞一條名為特里同的大河，流入一個稱為特里同湖的大湖(Lake Tritonis)。目前尚無共識其現代對應地點，可能是埃及的西瓦綠洲(Siwa Oasis)，或突尼西亞的Chott El Jerid鹽湖。<sup>5, 6</sup>

補充説明.納薩蒙人: （納薩蒙人）Nasamones 是居住在利比亞東南部西爾提斯灣（Gulf of Sirte）及奧吉拉綠洲（Awjila oasis）附近的游牧柏柏爾部族（Berber）。他們屬於努米底亞人（Numidian），使用四馬戰車，實行一夫多妻制，並曾與希臘殖民地發生衝突。
補充説明.卡利法尼斯: 利法尼斯（Calliphanes）是一位相信真正的幸福來自於擁有良好的品德和享受生活樂趣的古希臘哲學家。

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle, the Nistae are vividly brought to life as a striking figure: a creature with a perfectly normal human body, yet endowed with four eyes, gesturing expressively with one hand. It states:
“In Ethiopia, toward the west, some have four eyes.”1

Yet, if we turn to the Roman naturalist Pliny the Elder (23/24-79 CE), a different story emerges. In his Natural History (Book 6, Chapter 35), Pliny tells us that the creature dwelling along the coasts of the Red Sea does not literally have four eyes. Instead, this curious description is a metaphor celebrating remarkable eyesight and unparalleled skill with the bow. As Pliny explains:
“…the Nisicathae and Nisitae, names that mean 'men with three' or 'with four eyes' - not because they really are like that but because they have a particularly keen sight in using arrows.”2

This fascinating contradiction between the vivid medieval illustration and Pliny’s metaphorical account reveals much about the creative nature of medieval artists. They enjoy blending facts with fantasy, turning abstract qualities into sometimes uncanny images. Nistae stands as a perfect example of this embrace of ambiguity and hybridity.

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）中，尼西泰（Nistae）被生動描繪為一個引人注目的形象：擁有完全正常的人類身體，但配有四隻眼睛，並用一隻手做出富有表情的手勢。書中記載：
「在埃塞俄比亞西部，有些人有四隻眼睛。」1
然而，若轉向羅馬博物學家老普林尼（Pliny the Elder）（公元23/24-79年）的記載，情況則有所不同。在他的《博物志》（Natural History）（第6卷，第35章）中，普林尼指出，居住在紅海沿岸的這種生物並非真的擁有四隻眼睛。這一奇特的描述其實是一種比喻，用來讚美其卓越的視力和無與倫比的弓箭技巧。普林尼解釋說：
「……Nisicathae和Nisitae，這些名字意為‘三眼人’或‘四眼人’——並非因為他們真的如此，而是因為他們在使用箭矢時擁有特別敏銳的視力。」2
這種中世紀生動插圖與普林尼隱喻性描述之間的有趣矛盾，揭示了中世紀藝術家的創造力。他們喜歡將事實與幻想融合，將抽象特質轉化為有時令人驚異的形象。Nistae 正是這種模糊與混合特質的完美例證。

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle’s English translation, it states: “So in Eripia are people with necks like those of cranes, and bills for mouths”.1
Where was “Eripia”? A search for the name finds some places in present-day Greece and Macedonia.<sup>2</sup>

Jim Sebold, another commenter on the Nuremberg Chronicle states that the crane headed pople were metaphors for a wise judge, the long neck meant the judge’s words had to travel far from the heart before being spoken, allowing time for thought and fairness. He attributes a saying to Pliny the Elder3. However, it is not searchable in the works of Pliny. Instead, Siebold may have mis-read a footnote. It appears that the saying about crane-headed people and judges was in the Gesta Romanorum (Deeds of the Romans), a Latin work circulating in Europe around 1300 CE4, 5. In this 1905 English version, by Charles Swan it states:

“But one curiosity remains—the beautiful men of Europe who boast a crane’s head, neck, and beak. These, says the author of the Gesta, represent judges, who should have long necks and beaks, that what the heart thinks, may be long before it reach the mouth.”6

Gesta Romanorum may have had an influence in the creation of these illustrations in the Nuremberg Chronicle, since it was fairly widely available in Europe for centuries before the writing and publishing of the Nuremberg Chronicle.

This creature also reminds the students doing the project of the Rokurokubi from Japanese folklore — female yōkai (妖怪), formerly humans who in punishment for misdeeds, have their necks stretch out at night and attack small animals or lick up lamp oil (Meyer, n.d.), depicted below by Hokusai (1760 -1849 CE).

While both figures share the concept of a humanoid monster with a long neck, the meaning and significance of the images are very different, which one can expect considering the huge distance in time, place, and cultures between the creation of the stories and images.

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）的英文譯本中記載：「在埃里皮亞（Eripia）有人擁有像鶴一樣的脖子和鳥喙般的嘴巴」。<sup>1</sup>
「埃里皮亞」是什麼地方？查找此名稱可發現現今希臘和馬其頓有些地名相似。<sup>1</sup>

《紐倫堡編年史》的評論者Jim Sebold指出，鶴頭人是智慧法官的隱喻，長脖子象徵法官的話語必須從心底經過長時間思考後才說出，以確保公正。他將此說法歸於羅馬博物學家老普林尼3（Pliny the Elder），但在普林尼著作中找不到相關記載。Siebold可能誤讀了腳註。事實上，關於鶴頭人和法官的說法出自約1300年在歐洲流傳的拉丁文作品《羅馬人事蹟》（Gesta Romanorum）。4, 51905年查爾斯·斯旺（Charles Swan）英譯本中寫道：
「但有一件奇事——歐洲那些擁有鶴頭、長脖子和鳥喙的美男子。據《羅馬人事蹟》作者所說，他們象徵法官，法官應該有長脖子和鳥喙，這樣心裡所想的話，才能在到達嘴邊之前經過長時間的沉澱。」6
《羅馬人事蹟》可能影響了《紐倫堡編年史》中這些插圖的創作，因為該書在《紐倫堡編年史》寫作和出版前的幾個世紀，在歐洲相當流行。
這種生物也讓參與此專案的學生想起日本民間傳說中的轆轤首（Rokurokubi）——一種脖子會在夜晚伸長的女妖怪（Meyer, n.d.），下圖為葛飾北齋（1760-1849年）所繪。
雖然兩者都是長脖子的人形怪物，但由於故事和圖像產生於截然不同的時代、地點和文化，兩者的意義和象徵大相逕庭。

Introduction: In the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle it states:
“Some have the heads of dogs”1

Cynocephaly comes from the Greek word κυνοκέφαλοι, meaning “dog-headed” (kyno – dog, and kephalē, head)<sup>2</sup>. The term refers to mythical beings with a human body and a dog’s head. This idea appears in the myths and legends of various cultures, including ancient Egypt, Greece, India, China, and medieval Europe<sup>3</sup>.

In Egyptian mythology, Anubis and Wepwawet were cynocephalic gods, deities associated with the afterlife and funerary practices and seen as “openers of the way”.<sup>4</sup> They had the heads of jackals (a type of wild dog, whose scavenging led them to be associated with death in some cultures). This may symbolize their ability to transform between human and animal forms and life and death.

The ancient Greek writer Ctesias of Cnidus, royal physician to Artaxerxes II of Persia until 398/397 B.C.E<sup>5</sup> wrote about dog-headed people. In the work attributed to Ctsesias, dog-headed people are described as living in India, and reported to feed on birds and wild animals, communicate by barking, and mostly wore clothes made from leather. At the same time, they were also described as herders, fruit farmers, and raft-makers, who can live up to 200 years.<sup>6</sup> Megasthenes, who lived about 100 years later (dying ~ 290 BCE)<sup>7</sup>, according to Pliny, as reported by McCrindle told a similar tale.<sup>8</sup> The Greek historian Herodotus also mentioned similar beings in Libya<sup>9</sup>.

As more first-hand knowledge of the world and its peoples grew, the reported homes of dog-headed people grew more and more remote, and then mostly stopped around the time of the end of the Renaissance.<sup>10</sup>

「有些人長著狗的頭」1
犬首人一詞來自希臘語κυνοκέφαλοι，意為「狗頭」（kyno－狗，kephalē－頭）<sup>2</sup>。該詞指的是擁有人類身體但長有狗頭的神話生物。這一概念出現在多個文化的神話與傳說中，包括古埃及、希臘、印度、中國和中世紀歐洲<sup>3</sup>。
在埃及神話中，阿努比斯（Anubis）和韋普韋特（Wepwawet）是犬首神祇，與來世和葬禮儀式相關，被視為「開路者」。<sup>4</sup>他們擁有豺狼頭（豺狼是一種野狗，因為食腐而在某些文化中與死亡相關聯）。這象徵著他們能在人形與動物形態、生命與死亡之間轉換的能力。

古希臘作家克特西亞斯（Ctesias of Cnidus），波斯王阿爾塔薛西斯二世的御醫，於公元前398/397年之前<sup>5</sup>，曾撰寫關於犬首人的記載。克特西亞斯的著作中描述犬首人居住於印度，據說以鳥類和野獸為食，通過吠叫交流，並多穿皮革製成的衣服。同時，他們也是牧羊人、水果農和筏子製造者，壽命可達200年。<sup>6</sup>約一百年後的梅加斯塞尼斯（Megasthenes，約公元前290年逝世）也有類似記述<sup>7</sup> - 根據約翰·麥克林德（John W. McCrindle）的著作<sup>8</sup>。希臘歷史學家希羅多德（Herodotus）亦提及利比亞有類似生物。<sup>9</sup>
隨著對世界和各民族的第一手認識增加，犬首人的傳說居住地越來越偏遠，並於文藝復興末期基本消失。<sup>10</sup>

Introduction: The Arimaspi were a legendary one-eyed people of ancient mythology, said to inhabit the cold lands north of Scythia (modern-day Ukraine, southern Russia, and Kazakhstan), beyond the Riphean Mountains (a legendary mountain range to the ancient Greeks and Romans, never precisely located). They are famously known for fighting a never-ending war over gold with griffins (legendary creatures with the body, tail, and back legs of a lion; the head and wings of an eagle).<sup>1, 2</sup>
./images/staticPage/M09_page_1.png
Image source: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Scythia-Parthia_100_BC.png
The Nuremberg Chronicle itself locates them in India and states:
“Some have but one eye, and that in the middle of the forehead.”3.
The name "Arimaspi" itself speaks to their one-eyed nature. According to Herodotus, the name "Arimaspi" derived from the Scythian language: "arima" means "one" and "spou" means "eye,".4

Several ancient writers told the story of the Arimaspi. The famous Greek historian Herodotus mentioned them in his writings but expressed skepticism about their existence<sup>5</sup>. The Greek poet Aristeas of Proconnesus claimed that the Arimaspi lived north of a group called the Issedones (another eastern people of uncertain location) placing the griffins and the Hyperboreans even further north. Aristeas also described the migratory patterns of these northern groups, explaining how the warlike Arimaspi displaced the Issedones, who, in turn, displaced other tribes.<sup>6</sup>

In conclusion, the Arimaspi were mythical people whose existence was doubted even by ancient scholars. Their legendary battle with griffins for gold and their unique one-eyed trait made them a fascinating part of ancient mythology. Their story highlights our fascination with unknown lands and strange creatures, as well as themes of greed and conflict.

簡介: 阿里馬斯普人（Arimaspi）是古代神話中的傳說民族，據說居住在斯基泰（Scythia）以北的寒冷地帶（今烏克蘭、俄羅斯南部及哈薩克斯坦），超越了里菲安山脈（Riphean Mountains）（古希臘與羅馬傳說中的山脈，位置未明）。他們以與格里芬（Griffins）（獅子身體、尾巴與後腿，鷹頭與翅膀的傳說生物）為爭奪黃金而展開永無止境的戰爭聞名。<sup>1， 2</sup>

圖片來源： https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Scythia-Parthia_100_BC.png
《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）將他們定位於印度，並記載：
「有些人只有一隻眼睛，且位於額頭中央。」3
「阿里馬斯普」這個名字本身即反映了他們的獨眼特性。根據希羅多德（Herodotus）的說法，「Arimaspi」源自斯基泰語：「arima」意為「一」，「spou」意為「眼睛」。4

多位古代作家曾記述阿里馬斯普人的故事。著名希臘歷史學家希羅多德在其著作中提及他們，但對其存在持懷疑態度<sup>5</sup>。普羅科涅索斯的希臘詩人阿里斯提阿斯（Aristeas）聲稱阿里馬斯普人居住於伊賽多湼斯人（另一個位置不明的東方民族）以北，並將格里芬與極北的希伯波利安人（Hyperboreans）置於更北方。阿里斯提阿斯還描述了這些北方民族的遷徙模式，解釋了好戰的阿里馬斯普人如何驅逐伊賽多湼斯人，而後者又驅逐其他部落。<sup>6</sup>
總結而言，阿里馬斯普人是古代神話中的傳說民族，即使古代學者也對其存在表示懷疑。他們與格里芬為爭奪黃金而戰的傳說及其獨眼特徵，使他們成為古代神話中引人入勝的一部分。這些故事反映了人類對未知土地與奇異生物的好奇，以及貪婪與衝突的主題。

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle it states: “Item: Some are without heads, their eyes being in their shoulders”1.

These appear to be Blemyyes, also known as Akephaloi (a means “none” or “no” and kepahloi means head)2. One of the earliest glimpses of these strange creatures comes from the Greek historian Herodotus (c. 484- c425 BCE), who skillfully blended fact and folklore in his Histories(Book 4, Chapter 191). He situated the Akephaloi among the wild denizens of eastern Libya:

“For the eastern side of Libya, where the wanderers dwell, is low and sandy, as far as the river Triton; but westward of that the land of the husbandmen is very hilly, and abounds with forests and wild beasts. For this is the tract in which the huge serpents are found, and the lions, the elephants, the bears, the aspicks, and the horned asses. Here too are the dog-faced creatures, and the creatures without heads, whom the Libyans declare to have their eyes in their breasts; and also the wild men, and wild women, and many other far less fabulous beasts.”3

The location of the legendary headless people moves eastward in the writings of the Roman author Pliny the Elder (23/24-79 CE). Drawing on earlier Greek sources such as the historian Ctesias (~ 400 BCE), Pliny recounts a tribe in India with equally bizarre traits in his Natural History:

“Ctesias writes that also among a certain race of India the women bear children only once in their lifetime, and the children begin to turn grey directly after birth; he also describes a tribe of men called the Monocoli who have only one leg, and who move in jumps with surprising speed; the same are called the Umbrella-foot tribe, because in the hotter weather they lie on their backs on the ground and protect themselves with the shadow of their feet; and that they are not far away from the Trogodytae; and again westward from these there are some people without necks, having their eyes in their shoulders.”4

Yet the motif of the headless being transcends Greco-Roman imagination. In the Indian epic Ramayana, a demon named Kabandha emerges as a grotesque figure without a head, his eyes embedded in his chest—a presumed embodiment of the Akephaloi archetype.

“Headless, his mouth in his belly, covered with bristling hairs, in stature equal to a mountain, his complexion that of a dark cloud, terrible to look upon; his voice resounded like thunder. Shining like a lit torch, he seemed to emit sparks; his single eye, furnished with yellow lids opening in his breast, was strange and hideous, and this monster, possessed enormous teeth, was licking his lips.”5

Farther east, Chinese mythology offers a striking parallel in the Shan Hai Jing (Classic of Mountains and Seas). Here, the headless deity Xingtian clashes with the Supreme God Di. After losing his head, Xingtian transforms his nipples into eyes and his navel into a mouth. Undeterred, he dances fiercely with an axe and shield, a powerful symbol of defiance and unyielding spirit:

“Form Sky and the great god came to this place and fought for the godhead. The great god cut Form Sky’s head off and buried it on Mount Everram. So Form Sky made eyes from his nipples and a mouth from his navel, gripping his shield and battleaxe, he danced the Shield and Axe Dance.”6

This mythic image resonates deeply with the Akephaloi’s haunting visage depicted in the Nuremberg Chronicle, revealing a cross-cultural fascination with beings who defy human norms yet embody resilience, power, and an indomitable will.

簡介: 《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）記載：「有些人沒有頭，眼睛長在肩膀上」。<sup>1</sup>這些似乎是布勒米耶族（Blemmyes），也稱為無首族（Akephaloi，希臘語中 a 表示「無」，kephaloī 表示「頭」）<sup>2</sup>。最早對這些奇異生物的描述來自希臘歷史學家希羅多德（Herodotus）（約公元前484－425年），他在《歷史》（Histories）（第四卷，第191章）中巧妙融合事實與傳說，將無首族置於東利比亞的野蠻居民之中：
「利比亞東部，遊牧民居住之地，地勢低平多沙，延伸至特里同河；而西方農夫之地多丘陵，森林茂密，野獸繁多。此地有巨蛇、獅子、大象、熊、毒蛇及角驢。此處亦有犬首人及無首人，利比亞人稱其眼睛長在胸部；還有野人、野女及其他許多不那麼虛構的生物。」3
羅馬作家普林尼長者（Pliny the Elder） （公元23/24－79年）在《自然史》（Natural History）中，根據早期希臘史家克特西亞斯（Ctesias）（約公元前400年）的資料，將傳說中無首人的地點東移至印度，描述一支具有同樣怪異特徵的部族：
「克特西亞斯寫道，印度某族的婦女一生只生育一次，孩子出生後即開始變白髮；他還描述一支名為單足族（Monocoli）的部族，只有一條腿，跳躍前進速度驚人；他們又被稱為傘足族，因為炎熱時他們仰臥地面，用腳的陰影遮蔽自己；他們不遠處是特羅哥迪泰人（Trogodytae）；再往西，有些人沒有脖子，眼睛長在肩膀上。」4
無首人的形象超越了希臘羅馬的想像。在印度史詩《羅摩衍那》（Ramayana）中，有一個名為卡班達（Kabandha）的魔鬼，呈現無頭形象，眼睛長在胸部，被視為無首族的典型代表：
「無頭，口在腹部，身披剛毛，身形如山，膚色如烏雲，模樣可怖；聲音如雷鳴。閃耀如炬火，似發火花；唯一的眼睛長在胸中，帶黃瞼，怪異醜陋；此怪物擁有巨大牙齒，舔著嘴唇。」5
在更東方的中國神話中，《山海經》記載無首神刑天與天帝爭鬥。刑天被斬首後，將乳頭變成眼睛，肚臍變成嘴巴，手持斧盾，跳起激烈的斧盾舞，象徵不屈不撓的精神：
「形天與大帝相鬥，大帝斬其首，埋於恒山。形天乃以乳為目，以臍為口，執盾斧，舞斧盾舞。」6
這一神話形象與《紐倫堡編年史》中無首族的詭異面貌相呼應，展現了跨文化對於違反常規、卻象徵堅韌、力量與不屈意志生物的共同迷戀。

Introduction: In the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle it states:

“In Scythia, in a valley of Mount Imaus here called Timani there is a vast country called Abarimon, the inhabitants of which are a savage race, whose feet are turned backwards; but they possess wonderful velocity, and wander about indiscriminately with the wild beasts. They cannot breathe in any other climate but their own, for which reason it is impossible to take them before any of the neighboring kings; nor could any of them be brought before Alexander the Great as a tribe from India with a unique feature: their feet face backward and have eight toes each.”1

Havadas (the translator) then notes “Pliny, Natural History, VII, c.2. Aulus Gellius also relates this, among other wonderful tales, in the chapter, “On the Miraculous Wonders of Barbarous Nations,” IX c.4. He [Pliny] cites among his authorities, Aristeas and Isigonus, whom he designates as “writers of no mean authority.”<sup>2</sup>
On the following page, the translation also states: “On Mount Nulo (here called Milo) there is a race of men whose feet are turned backwards, with eight toes on each foot.”<sup>3</sup>
The main source of the Nuloi appears to be from ancient Roman author Pliny the Elder in his work Natural History (1942). He writes:
“Upon a certaine mountaine named Milus, there be men whose feet grow the other way backward, and of either foot they have eight toes, as Megatheres doth report.”

The students doing this project speculate that perhaps the reason that tales of people with backward-facing feet located them in far-away mountains is that such feet could conceivably be an aid to living and traveling in mountainous surroundings.

簡介: 《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）英文譯本記載：

「在斯基泰（Scythia），伊瑪烏斯山（Mount Imaus）（此處稱為提馬尼[Timani]）的一個山谷中，有一片廣袤的土地名為阿巴里蒙（Abarimon），居住著一種野蠻族群，他們的腳是向後的；但他們速度驚人，與野獸一同四處遊蕩。他們無法在其他氣候中呼吸，因此無法被帶到鄰近的任何國王面前；也無法被帶到亞歷山大大帝 （Alexander the Great）面前，作為來自印度的部族，具有獨特特徵：腳向後且每隻腳有八趾。」1
譯者哈達瓦斯（Havadas）註解：「普林尼（Pliny the Elder），《自然史》第七卷第二章。奧勒斯·蓋留斯（Aulus Gellius）也在《野蠻民族奇異奇蹟》第九卷第四章中記述此事。他（普林尼）引用的權威包括阿里斯泰亞斯（Aristeas）和伊西戈努斯（Isigonus），被稱為‘具有不俗權威的作家’。」<sup>2</sup>
下一頁譯文亦提及：「努洛山（Nulo）（此處稱為米洛[Milo]）有一族人，他們的腳向後，且每隻腳有八趾。」<sup>3</sup>
關於努洛伊人（Nuloi）的主要資料來自古羅馬作家老普林尼的《自然史》（Natural History）（1942年版），他寫道：
「在一座名為米洛（Milus）的山上，有一種人，他們的腳向後生長，每隻腳有八趾，正如梅加特雷斯（Megatheres）所報告的。」
參與此研究的學生推測，關於腳向後的人被安置在遙遠山區的傳說，可能是因為這種腳型有助於在山地環境中生活和行走。

補充説明.斯基泰: 斯基泰 (Scythia) 是古希臘羅馬世界中定義的一個地理區域，主要涵蓋位於黑海北部的頓巴斯草原地區。
補充説明.米洛: 古籍中提及的米洛斯山 (Mountain Milus)，特別是老普林尼 (Pliny the Elder) 所述，被認為位於印度境內。

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle’s English translation, it states:
“In Lybia [sic]... Some are double-sexed, the right breast male, the left one female. They are indiscriminate in their associations with one another and bear children.”1

This seems to align with the depicted androgynous figures, blending both male and female physical traits. The hair is styled asymmetrically—short on one side and long on the other. Likewise, one side of their face sports facial hair while the other remains clean-shaven. This duality extends to their bodies as well, with one side of the chest flat and the other full.

The students doing this research decided they wanted to consider the androgynous figures to be “Amazons”, mythical warrior women<sup>2,3</sup>.  From their reading they think that people in Europe thousands of years ago ancient world placed the Amazons in various locales: from the wilds near the Black Sea to the distant reaches of Asia and Africa.
Apollonius Rhodius, in his epic Argonautica (Book II), vividly evokes the terrain associated with the Amazons:

“This [river] flows down to the plain from lofty mountains, which, men say, are called the Amazonian mountains. Thence it spreads inland over a hilly country straight forward; wherefrom its streams go winding on, and they roll on, this way and that ever more, wherever best they can reach the lower ground, one at a distance and another near at hand; and many streams are swallowed up in the sand and are without a name; but, mingled with a few, the main stream openly bursts with its arching crest of foam into the inhospitable Pontus. And they would have tarried there and have closed in battle with the Amazons, and would have fought not without bloodshed for the Amazons were not gentle foes and regarded not justice, those dwellers on the Doeantian plain; but grievous insolence and the works of Ares were all their care; for by race they were the daughters of Ares and the nymph Harmonia, who bare to Ares war-loving maids, wedded to him in the glens of the Acmonian wood had not the breezes of Argestes come again from Zeus.”4

Expanding on this legendary narrative, historian Martini Fisher recounts how the warrior queen Penthesilea led her Amazon army to aid the Trojans in their epic war against the Greeks. Her battlefield valor was legendary, yet her fate was tragic—she was slain by Achilles, the mightiest Greek warrior, who mourned her death deeply.<sup>5</sup>

Marked by a burnt right breast and indomitable spirit, the Amazons continue to inspire awe and fascination. Their stories, woven through myth and history, remind us of a world where women warriors challenged gods and heroes alike, carving a legacy that endures across time and culture.

簡介: 《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）英文譯本記載：
「利比亞（Lybia）……有些人是雙性，右胸為男性，左胸為女性。他們彼此間無所區分地交往，並能生育子女。」1
這與書中描繪的雌雄同體形象相符，融合了男性與女性的身體特徵。頭髮呈不對稱造型——一側短髮，另一側長髮；臉部一側有鬍鬚，另一側則乾淨剃淨。這種二元性也延伸至身體，一側胸部平坦，另一側豐滿。
參與此研究的學生決定將這些雌雄同體的形象視為「亞馬遜族」（Amazons），即神話中的女戰士<sup>2, 3</sup>。根據他們的閱讀，古歐洲人數千年前將亞馬遜族置於多個地點：從黑海（Black Sea）附近的荒野，到亞洲與非洲的遙遠地區。
阿波羅尼奧斯·羅迪烏斯（Apollonius Rhodius）在其史詩《阿爾戈英雄記》（Argonautica）（第二卷）中生動描繪了與亞馬遜族相關的地形：

「這條河從高聳的山脈流向平原，人們稱這些山為亞馬遜山脈。河水向內陸蔓延，穿越多丘陵地帶，河流曲折蜿蜒，時而遠時而近，許多支流消失於沙中無名無跡；主流則帶著拱形的浪花奔向荒涼的彭特斯海 （Pontus）。他們本欲在此與亞馬遜族決戰，並非無血腥，因為亞馬遜族並非溫和敵人，也不講正義，那些居住在多安提安平原（Doeantian）的人；他們只顧殘暴傲慢與戰神阿瑞斯（Ares）的行徑；因為他們乃是阿瑞斯與仙女哈爾莫尼亞（Harmonia）的女兒，哈爾莫尼亞為阿瑞斯生下這些熱愛戰爭的少女，她們在阿克莫尼安森林（Acmonian wood）的幽谷中與阿瑞斯結合，若非宙斯（Zeus）派遣阿爾格斯特斯（Argestes）的風再次吹來。」4
歷史學家馬丁尼·費雪（Martini Fisher）進一步敘述了女戰士女王彭特西萊亞（Penthesilea）如何率領亞馬遜軍隊協助特洛伊人（Trojans）對抗希臘人的史詩戰爭。她在戰場上的英勇傳奇聞名，但命運悲慘——她被最強大的希臘戰士阿基里斯（Achilles）所殺，阿基里斯為她的死深感哀悼。<sup>5</sup>
亞馬遜族以其燒灼的右胸和不屈不撓的精神，持續激發人們的敬畏與著迷。她們的故事交織於神話與歷史之中，提醒我們那個女性戰士挑戰神祇與英雄的世界，留下跨越時代與文化的永恆傳奇。

Introduction: Monopods (meaning, “one foot”) are also referred to as Sciopod, Skiaod or Skiapode, (meaning “shadow foot”) are often associated with inhabitants of hot climates.<sup>1</sup> These beings are said to live in arid, often desert-like regions — an environment that contributes to the idea of them using their large foot as a sunshade.
In the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle, there are two texts that may relate to the earlier traditions of monopods.

“Others have very large feet and legs, but no paunches, and are marvelously fleet of foot. In the summertime, while lying on their backs, they protect themselves against the sun by the shade of their feet”.2
“In Ethiopia, toward the west, are people with but one foot, which is very broad. They are so fleet that they pursue the wild animals”.3
Havadas, the translator, supplies the following foot-note relating it to Pliny:

“He (Ctesias) speaks also of another race of men, known as Monocoli, who have only one leg, but are able to leap with surprising agility. The same people are also called Sciapodae, because they are in the habit of lying on their backs during the time of extreme heat and protect themselves from the sun by the shade of their feet. (Pliny, Natural History, VII, ch. 2).4
Tales of monopods have a long history in Western literature. A first known mention is from  a play of Aristophanes, The Birds (first performed in 414 BCE), in an English translation:
“By that tribe of men with such huge feet
they use them for a shade retreat,
there’s stands a lake where Socrates,
deceives men’s souls, that unwashed tease.”5

As mentioned above, Pliny the Elder (~ 23-79 CE) wrote of them in his Natural History.  Augustine of Hippo (354-430 CE) in his work The City of God mentions them (along with other monstrous beings) that one can be sceptical of.

“So, too, they tell of a race who have two feet but only one leg, and are of marvellous swiftness, though they do not bend the knee: they are called Skiopodes, because in the hot weather they lie down on their backs and shade themselves with their feet…But we are not bound to believe all we hear of these monstrosities.”6

Still, a good story about monsters is hard to drop, and thus such creatures have continued to appear in tales of imaginary and far away places up through the 20th century, where they are presented as a group of people called “Dufflepuds” in a children’s novel The Voyage of the Dawn Treader.7
