簡介: 獨足族（意為「一足」），亦稱為傘足人 / 影足族（Sciopod、Skiaod 或 Skiapode，意為「影子之足」），常被認為是居住於炎熱氣候地區的族群<sup>1</sup>。此類生物據說生活在乾旱、常似沙漠的環境中，因此產生了他們用巨大腳掌遮陽的想像。
《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）英文譯本中有兩段文字可能與獨足族的早期傳說相關：
「此外，有些人擁有非常巨大的腳和腿，但沒有大腹部，且腳步極其敏捷。夏天時，他們仰躺著，用腳的陰影遮擋陽光。」2
「此外：在埃塞俄比亞西部，有一種人只有一隻腳，且非常寬大。他們速度極快，能追逐野獸。」3
譯者哈達瓦斯（Havadas）在腳註中引述普林尼的說法：
「克特西亞斯（Ctesias）也提到另一種人種，稱為獨腿族（Monocoli），他們只有一條腿，但能以驚人的敏捷跳躍。這些人也被稱為影足族（Sciapodae），因為在酷熱時節，他們習慣仰躺，用腳的陰影遮陽。（普林尼 [Pliny the Elder] ，《自然史》第七卷第二章）」4
獨足族的傳說在西方文學中有悠久歷史。最早的記載之一來自阿里斯多芬（Aristophanes）於公元前414年首演的戲劇《鳥》（The Birds），英文譯文中寫道：
「那一族人腳大如舟，
他們用腳遮陽避暑，
有湖泊立於彼岸，
蘇格拉底欺騙未洗靈魂。」5
如前所述，老普林尼（約公元23-79年）在《自然史》中亦有記載。希波的奧古斯丁（Augustine of Hippo，354-430年）在《上帝之城》中提及此類生物（與其他怪物一同），並表示人們可對此持懷疑態度：
「同樣，他們也講述一種人有兩隻腳但只有一條腿，速度奇快，膝蓋不彎曲：他們被稱為影足族，因為在炎熱天氣會仰躺，用腳遮陽……但我們不必相信所有關於這些怪物的傳聞。」6
然而，有關怪物的故事總是難以放下，因此這類生物一直出現在關於遙遠奇幻之地的傳說中，直到20世紀，在兒童小說《黎明號航行記》（The Voyage of the Dawn Treader）<sup>7</sup>中被描繪為一群名為「達弗爾帕德」（Dufflepuds）的人。

Introduction: The Astomi, also known as the Strawmen, are vividly depicted in the Nuremberg Chronicle with remarkably tiny mouths—so small that they can only sip through a straw from a tumbler. Interestingly, while the book describes them as “having holes in their faces instead of nostrils,” the accompanying illustration seems to contradict this detail. Yet, the text goes on to paint a fascinating picture of their unique existence, either one or two types of people:

“At the very extremity of India, on the eastern side, near the source of the river Ganges, there is a nation of people who have no mouths; their bodies are rough and hairy, and they cover themselves with a down plucked from the leaves of trees. These people subsist only by breathing and by the odors which they inhale through their nostrils. They take neither food nor drink. When they go on a long journey they carry with them only various odoriferous roots, flowers, and wild apples. Should they encounter an odor of unusual strength, they die”.1
and

“Item: Toward Paradise, by the River Ganges, are people who do not eat. Their mouths are so small that they are obliged to drink through a straw. They live upon the odor of fruits and flowers. They quickly die if they encounter evil odors. ”2
Artistic representations of the creature’s appearance seem to vary, adding to the mystery surrounding these enigmatic beings.
In his Natural History, Pliny the Elder offers a different elaboration of the creature’s appearance, drawing on the Greek historian Megasthenes’ description:

“At the extreme boundary of India to the East, near the source of the Ganges, he puts the Astomi tribe, that has no mouth and a body hairy all over; they dress in cotton-wool and live only on the air they breathe and the scent they inhale through their nostrils.”3

This vivid description contrasts sharply with the Nuremberg Chronicle illustration, which shows the Astomi with a mouth and smooth skin instead, highlighting the variability and ambiguity in how these mythical Strawmen have been imagined over time.

簡介: 阿斯托米族（Astomi），又稱為吸管人（Strawmen） ，在《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）中被生動描繪，擁有極其微小的嘴巴 —— 小到只能用吸管從杯子中吸取液體。有趣的是，書中描述他們「臉上有洞而非鼻孔」，但隨附的插圖似乎與此細節相矛盾。然而，文本進一步描繪了他們獨特的生存方式，可能存在一種或兩種不同類型的人：
「在印度東部的極端邊境，靠近恆河源頭，有一群沒有嘴巴的人；他們的身體粗糙多毛，並用樹葉上的絨毛遮蓋身體。這些人僅靠呼吸和從鼻孔吸入的氣味維生。他們不吃不喝。當他們長途跋涉時，只攜帶各種芳香的根、花和野蘋果。若遇到異常強烈的氣味，他們便會死亡。」1
以及
「此外：在靠近恆河的天堂附近，有一群不吃食物的人。他們的嘴巴非常小，只能用吸管飲水。他們靠水果和花朵的香氣為生。若遇到惡臭，便會迅速死亡。」2
關於這種生物外貌的藝術表現多有差異，增添了這些神秘存在的謎團。
在《自然史》（Natural History）中，老普林尼（Pliny the Elder）根據希臘歷史學家梅加斯塞尼（Megasthenes）的描述，對該生物的外貌有不同的闡述：
「在印度東部極端邊界，靠近恆河源頭，他將阿斯托米族置於此地，他們沒有嘴巴，身體全身多毛；穿著棉絨，只靠呼吸的空氣和從鼻孔吸入的香氣生活。」3
這段生動的描述與《紐倫堡編年史》插圖形成鮮明對比，後者顯示阿斯托米族有嘴巴且皮膚光滑，凸顯了這些神話中吸管人的形象隨時間變化而存在的多樣性與模糊性。

Introduction: In the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle, it states:
“In this country [by the Ganges] there are also people without noses, their faces flat”.1
Pliny the Elder, in his work Natural History, (Book 7, Chapter 2) reported:
“Megasthenes places among the Nomades of India, a people who are called Scyritæ. These have merely holes in their faces instead of nostrils, and flexible feet, like the body of the serpent.2

Monge suggests that such a description may be related to people who may have had what are now “known embryogenesis defects, including arrhinia”<sup>3</sup> a rare disorder where people are born without noses.<sup>4</sup>
By some strange transmission or ideas, or horrors, this is also a bit similar to the look of Lord Voldemort (the evil antagonist) as first described in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire5.

簡介: 《紐倫堡編年史》（Nuremberg Chronicle）英文譯本中記載：
「在這個國家〔恆河附近〕也有無鼻子的人，他們的臉扁平。」1
老普林尼在其著作《自然史》（第七卷第二章）中報導：
「梅加斯塞尼（Megasthenes）將印度的游牧民族中列出一種稱為斯基利泰人的族群。他們臉上沒有鼻孔，只有洞穴，腳靈活如蛇身。」2
蒙日（Monge）提出，這樣的描述可能與現代所知的「胚胎發育缺陷，包括無鼻症（arrhinia）」有關，這是一種罕見疾病<sup>3</sup>， 患者天生沒有鼻子<sup>4</sup>。
某種奇異的傳說或想像，使得這種形象與《哈利波特與火盃的考驗》中首次描述的邪惡反派佛地魔（Lord Voldemort）的外貌有些相似。<sup>5</sup>

Introduction: In the Nuremberg Chronicle, the Amyctyrae are portrayed as creatures distinguished by absurdly large lower lips, so pronounced that they envelop at least one-third of their faces. The accompanying text vividly states,
“In this country there are also people without noses, their faces flat. Some have lower lips so large that they cover the entire face.”1

Cartographic historian and commentator on the Nuremberg Chronicle Jim Siebold elaborated (without citations) that these creatures “subsist on raw meat and can use their giant lower lip as an umbrella against the sun.”2 This fantastical description, however, finds an echo in real-world practices.

The practice of lip modification is not entirely rooted in myths. It can be found among indigenous peoples in Africa and the Americas, involving the stretching of the lower lip through the insertion of progressively larger plates or discs crafted from materials like clay or wood. These customs offer a tangible counterpart to the Chronicle’s exaggerated depiction.<sup>3</sup>
In the Mursi tribe of Ethiopia, lip plates serve not only as a form of aesthetic expression but also as powerful symbols linked to an individual’s strengths and weaknesses, according to LaTosky:

“For example, a woman who has not had her lip cut or does not wear her lip-plate in certain situations becomes more vulnerable in the presence of men. Mursi women and men often refer to her as being lazy and as someone who does things in a hasty and clumsy manner, especially in the presence of men.” 4
“Similarly, a woman who has had her lip cut is said to have healthier cows and therefore more milk than a woman without a lip-plate.”5
LaTosky added that the lip-plates come in the form of clay – in red, reddish brown, black or white colour – or wood, which are typically made by men.
“Wooden lip-plates (burgui), typically made only by men, are said to be the largest and most beautiful lip-plates worn by unmarried Mursi girls and women.”6

Given these practices, the students believe that the Chronicle’s depiction of the Amyctyrae may have drawn inspiration from some African tribal people’s practicing lip plate insertion<sup>7</sup> (although other groups have had similar practices)<sup>8</sup>. The depiction may blend elements of reality with the exaggerations common in medieval descriptions of faraway lands.

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》 （Nuremberg Chronicle） 中，阿米克特雷族（Amyctyrae）被描繪為擁有極為誇張的大下唇的生物，下唇大到至少覆蓋了三分之一的臉部。隨附的文字生動描述：
「在這個國家裡也有無鼻子的人，他們的臉扁平。有些人的下唇大到覆蓋整張臉。」1
地圖史學家及《紐倫堡編年史》評論家吉姆·賽博德（Jim Siebold）進一步闡述（未附引文）這些生物「以生肉為食，並能用巨大的下唇當作遮陽傘。」<sup>2</sup>
然而，這種奇幻的描述在現實世界中有其呼應。
唇盤改造並非完全源自神話。這種習俗存在於非洲和美洲的原住民族中，透過逐漸插入由黏土或木材製成的越來越大的唇盤或唇片來拉伸下唇。這些習俗為《編年史》中誇張的描繪提供了具體的對應。
在埃塞俄比亞的穆爾西族（Mursi）中，唇盤不僅是美學表達的一種形式，更是與個人優劣勢相關的強烈象徵，根據拉托斯基（LaTosky）的研究：
「例如，一個未割唇或在特定場合不佩戴唇盤的女性，在男性面前會變得較為脆弱。穆爾西的男女常稱她為懶惰，且行事草率笨拙，尤其是在男性面前。」4
「同樣地，有割唇的女性據說擁有較健康的牛群，因此比沒有唇盤的女性擁有更多的牛奶。」5
拉托斯基補充說，唇盤有黏土製和木製兩種，通常由男性製作。
「木製唇盤（burgui）通常只有男性製作，被認為是未婚穆爾西女孩和婦女所佩戴的最大且最美麗的唇盤。」6
基於這些習俗，研究者認為《編年史》對阿米克特雷族的描繪可能受到某些非洲部落實行唇盤插入習俗的啟發<sup>7</sup>（儘管其他族群也有類似做法）<sup>8</sup>。這種描繪或許融合了現實元素與中世紀對遙遠土地誇張描述的成分。

Introduction: In the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle, it states:

“Item: In Ethiopia some wander about with their bodies bent downward in the manner of animals; and some of these live four hundred years. Item: Some have horns, long noses and goat’s feet; and these are spoken of throughout the legends of St. Anthony.”1

Aegipan, means “Goat-Pan”, reflecting an association with the god Pan found in ancient sources. In Fabulae, the Roman mythographer Hyginus, translated by Mary Grant, suggests that Pan transformed into Aegipan and was subsequently identified with the constellation Capricorn. Hyginus writes:

“When the god in Egypt feared the monster Typhon, Pan bade them transform themselves into wild beasts the more easily to deceive him. Jove later killed him with a thunderbolt. By the will of the gods, since by his warning they had avoided Typhon's violence, Pan was put among the number of the stars, Since at that time he had changed himself into a goat, he was called Aegocerus. We call him Capricorn.”2

Hyginus also offers a fascinating account of Aegipan’s parentage, describing him as the son of Zeus and a goat or of Zeus and Aega, sometimes identified as Pan’s wife. This lineage underscores his hybrid nature, part goat and occasionally part fish: “Aegipan by the she-goat Boetis.”<sup>3</sup>

Aegipan’s most celebrated role unfolds during the epic struggle between Zeus and the monstrous Typhon. After Zeus was defeated and his sinews stolen by Typhon, it was Aegipan, alongside Hermes, who stealthily recovered and restored them, enabling Zeus to regain his strength and ultimately triumph:
“When Zeus in his contest with the Titans was deprived of the sinews of his hands and feet, Hermes and Aegipan secretly restored them to him and fitted them in their proper places.”4

This clever act of assistance highlights Aegipan’s importance as a figure associated with transformation and cunning. In recognition of his heroic deeds, Aegipan was immortalized among the stars as the constellation Capricornus, the sea-goat, a celestial symbol of his hybrid form: “He was transferred to the stars, and the sea-goat form is linked to the zodiac sign Capricornus.”<sup>5</sup>

Interestingly, Plutarch preserves a Roman tradition that diverges sharply from the Greek myth. According to this account, Aegipan was born from the incestuous union of Valeria of Tusculum and her father Valerius, and in this context, he is equated with Silvanus, the Roman god of the woods:

“According to a Roman tradition mentioned by Plutarch (Parallel. 22), Aegipan had sprung from the incestuous intercourse of Valeria of Tusculum and her father Valerius, and was considered only a different name for Silvanus.”6
This variation illustrates the fluidity of Aegipan’s identity across cultures and time, blending mythological, local, and religious traditions.

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》 (Nuremberg Chronicle)的英文譯本中，艾吉潘（Aegipan）被生動地描述為「一個揮舞手勢的身影，擁有兩根長角、長鼻子和分蹄的腳。」隨附的插圖描繪他長有兩根優雅彎曲的角、馬蹄形的腳，左手正做出半途的手勢，強調他在文本中充滿動感且神秘的存在感。
艾吉潘這個名字本身意為「山羊潘」（Goat-Pan），反映出他與古代文獻中潘神（Pan）的深厚關聯。在羅馬神話學者海吉納斯（Hyginus）所著的《神話集》（Fabulae）中（由瑪麗·格蘭特翻譯），提到潘變身為艾吉潘，隨後被認為是摩羯座星座的化身。海吉納斯寫道：
「當埃及的神祇懼怕怪物提豐（Typhon）時，潘命令他們變成野獸，以便更容易欺騙提豐。後來朱庇特（Jove）用雷電擊殺了他。由於眾神的意願，因為他們藉由潘的警告避免了提豐的暴行，潘被列入星宿之中。當時他已變成一隻山羊，因此被稱為艾戈塞魯斯（Aegocerus）。我們稱他為摩羯座。」1
海吉納斯還提供了關於艾吉潘身世的有趣說法，描述他是宙斯與一隻母山羊的兒子，或是宙斯與艾加（Aega，常被認為是潘的妻子）的兒子。這段血統凸顯了他混合的本質，部分是山羊，有時又帶有魚的特徵：「艾吉潘是母山羊博伊蒂斯（Boetis）所生。」<sup>2</sup>
艾吉潘最著名的角色出現在宙斯（Zeus）與怪物提豐的史詩般鬥爭中。當宙斯被擊敗，筋腱被提豐奪走時，正是艾吉潘與赫爾墨斯（Hermes）秘密地奪回並恢復了這些筋腱，使宙斯得以重獲力量並最終勝利：
「當宙斯與泰坦神戰鬥時，手腳的筋腱被奪走，赫爾墨斯與艾吉潘秘密將它們復原並安置於正確位置。」 3
這一巧妙的幫助行動突顯艾吉潘作為變形與狡猾象徵的重要性。為了表彰他的英勇事蹟，艾吉潘被永生化為星座摩羯座（Capricornus），即海山羊，象徵他混合的形態：「他被升入星空，海山羊的形象與摩羯座星座相連。」<sup>4</sup>
有趣的是，普魯塔克（Plutarch）保存了一則與希臘神話截然不同的羅馬傳說。根據此說法，艾吉潘是圖斯庫盧姆（Tusculum）的瓦萊莉亞（Valeria）與其父瓦萊里烏斯（Valerius）亂倫所生，在此背景下，他被視為森林之神西爾瓦努斯（Silvanus）的另一個名字：
「根據普魯塔克(Plutarch)[《平行傳記》22章]所述的羅馬傳說，艾吉潘是圖斯庫盧姆的瓦萊莉亞與其父瓦萊里烏斯亂倫所生，被認為只是西爾瓦努斯的另一個名字。」5
此變異展示了艾吉潘身份在不同文化與時代中的流動性，融合了神話、本土及宗教傳統。

Introduction: In the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle, there are two texts that may relate to the image of the one-legged hunter.

“Item: Others have very large feet and legs, but no paunches, and are marvelously fleet of foot. In the summertime, while lying on their backs, they protect themselves against the sun by the shade of their feet”.1
“Item: In Ethiopia, toward the west, are people with but one foot, which is very broad. They are so fleet that they pursue the wild animals”.2

Basically, the text that describe them are the same as the ones used to describe the monopods, based on Pliny’s passing on of Ctesisas’s tales.3 Monge also suggests that such stories in Plainy may have had their origin indiseases like podoconiosis or elephantiasis.4 Both podoconiosis and elephantisis are tropical diseases5, 6. However, neither disease makes people faster and more agile, quite the opposite.

Introduction: In the English version of the Nuremberg Chronicle, it states:
“In Scythia are people with hoofs like a horse.”1
The name “Hippopodes” means horse-foot ( “hippo” is Greek for  “horse,” and “pous” meaning “foot” — a literal nod to their equine extremities.

Tracing the Hippopodes beyond the Nuremberg Chronicle, their name and legend appear in earlier classical sources. The ancient Roman naturalist Pliny the Elder (23/24-79 CE) mentions the Hippopodes as a swift-footed tribe with horse’s feet, residing near Cadiz. He writes:

“Also some islands called the Oeonae are reported of which the inhabitants live on birds' eggs and oats, and others on which people are born with horses' feet, which gives them their Greek name Hippopodes; there are others called the Islands of the Phanesii in which the natives have very large ears covering the whole of their bodies, which are otherwise left naked.”2

Similarly, the Greek geographer Pomponius Mela, writing in the first century CE, refers to this tribe in his geographical work: “There are also the Hippopodes, who have the feet of a horse and live in the far north, renowned for their speed.”<sup>3</sup>

Together, these accounts weave a fascinating tapestry of myth and geography, situating the Hippopodes as mysterious inhabitants of the world’s remote regions. Their horse-like feet symbolize not only physical distinctiveness but also a liminal existence at the edges of human civilization and the unknown.

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》 （Nuremberg Chronicle）的英文版中提到：
「斯基提亞（Scythia）有一種人，腳像馬蹄。」1
「Hippopodes」一詞意為馬足（「hippo」是希臘語的「馬」，「pous」意為「腳」），字面上指他們像馬一樣的腳。
追溯馬足人的記載，除了《紐倫堡編年史》，他們的名字和傳說也出現在更早的古典文獻中。古羅馬博物學家老普林尼（Pliny the Elder）（公元23/24-79年）提到馬足人是一個腳快如馬蹄的部落，居住在加的斯附近。他寫道：
「還有一些被稱為奧奧奈（Oeonae）的島嶼，居民以鳥蛋和燕麥為食，還有一些島上的人天生有馬蹄腳，因此得名希臘語‘馬足人’；還有被稱為法內西群島（Phanesii）的島嶼，當地人耳朵非常大，覆蓋全身，身體其他部分則赤裸。」2
同樣，希臘地理學家龐波尼烏斯·梅拉（Pomponius Mela）在一世紀的地理著作中也提到這個部落<sup>3</sup>：
「還有馬足人，他們有馬的腳，居住在遙遠的北方，以速度聞名。」
這些記載共同編織出一幅神話與地理交織的畫卷，將馬足人定位為世界偏遠地區神秘的居民。他們像馬一樣的腳不僅象徵著身體的特殊性，也象徵著他們處於人類文明邊緣與未知世界的過渡地帶。

補充説明.斯基提亞（Scythia）: 位於黑海 (Black Sea) 南部以北、多瑙河與頓河之間的古代草原地區。
補充説明.法內西群島（Phanesii）: 古代傳說中位於斯基提亞附近，居住著全身被巨大耳朵覆蓋民族的神秘島嶼。

Introduction: In the English translation of the Nuremberg Chronicle, it states:

“Some are a cubit1 [18 in. 457 mm] in height, and do not live more than eight years. They live in the mountains of India, near the great sea, in a wholesome and ever verdant region. They conduct an unusual warfare against the cranes. Their wives bear at the age of five years”.2

The term “pygmy” appears to have first appeared in the Iliad3, attributed to Homer (8th or 9th century BCE)4, describing a battle where the Trojans were compared to cranes arising at dawn to attack and kill “pygmy men”.

“Now when they were marshalled, the several companies with their captains, the Trojans came on with clamour and with a cry like birds, even as the clamour of cranes ariseth before the face of heaven, when they flee from wintry storms and measureless rain, and with clamour fly toward the streams of Ocean, bearing slaughter and death to Pigmy men, and in the early dawn they offer evil battle.”5

Based on this, stories of people so small that they fight cranes may have already been circulating among Greek speakers almost 3,000 years ago. The research on Theoi.com bears this out, showing many references to Pygmies battling cranes across centuries.<sup>6</sup>

Myths and stories of “little people” are wide-spread across human cultures, up to the present day.7 Some are magical, or have supernatural powers, while others are just extremely small. So, it is not surprising that they appear in the Nuremberg Chronicle.

簡介: 在《紐倫堡編年史》 （Nuremberg Chronicle）的英文譯本中提到：
「……有些人身高約一肘1（18英寸，457毫米） ，壽命不超過八年。他們生活在印度的山區，靠近大海，居住在一個健康且常綠的地區。他們與鶴展開非凡的戰爭。他們的妻子五歲便能生育。」2
「矮人族」 （Pygmies） 一詞似乎首次出現在《伊利亞特》（Ilaid）<sup>3</sup>中，該作品歸於荷馬（Homer）（公元前8或9世紀）<sup>4</sup>，描述了一場戰鬥，特洛伊人（Trojans）被比作黎明時分起飛攻擊並殺死「矮人族」的鶴群。
當各隊伍與隊長整裝待發時，特洛伊人喧囂著前進，發出如鳥鳴般的呼喊，正如鶴群在冬季暴風雨和無盡雨水來臨前飛翔於天空前的喧囂，帶著殺戮與死亡飛向大洋之流，黎明時分向矮人族發起惡戰。」5
基於此，關於如此矮小以至於能與鶴作戰的人們的故事，早在近三千年前的希臘語使用者中就已流傳。Theoi.com上的研究亦證實了這一點，顯示跨越數個世紀有許多關於矮人族與鶴戰鬥的記載。<sup>6</sup>
「小人」的神話與故事在人類文化中廣泛存在，直到今日仍然流傳。有些具備魔法或超自然力量，有些則僅是體型極小。因此，他們出現在《紐倫堡編年史》中並不令人驚訝。
